story: Queen Elizabeth II has been on the throne since February 6, 1952. In that time, the monarchy's position within British society has changed dramatically and is almost unrecognisable to how it was seen in the 1950s. Alongside Prince Philip, she oversaw modernisation that thrust the Crown into the twentieth century &ndash and her decision to welcome TV cameras in the 1960s was a major step in that direction.                How the Queen was 'passionately LOVED' by Winston Churchill                The incriminating evidence Diana found PROVING Charles and Camilla's aRichard Cawston&rsquos BBC documentary team followed the Royal Family for 18 months as they went about their day-to-day lives.Their activities ranged from Prince Philip grilling sausages at Balmoral to the Queen making small-talk with U.S. President Richard Nixon.It was originally broadcast on June 21, 1969, the year Prince Charles was invested as Prince of Wales, to rave reviews and major audiences in the U.S. and in the U.K.The behind-closed-door documentary was hugely symbolic as it was the first time Britons were able to see the monarchy without the pomp and ceremony of public occasions.&nbspThe Royal Family enjoy breakfast together (Image: BBC)If the Queen had chosen not to take this step, she risked public perception turning against the monarchy, which could have been seen as an outdated institution.&nbspHowever, the documentary was regarded as so intrusive and revealing of the Royal Family that it had to be withdrawn for over 45 years and it has been locked away at Her Majesty&rsquos command in the BBC vaults.The premise was for the public to get an idea of what life in the modern royal court of 1969 was like.Cameras followed the Royal Family around for a whole year, accompanying the Queen on tours of Chile and Brazil, while also touring Malta and Cambridge with Prince Charles.They also shot more than 40 hours of film in Sandringham, Balmoral, Buckingham Palace, Windsor and Holyrood, as well as on the Royal Yacht, the Royal Train and aircraft of the Queen's Flight.Princess Anne notoriously hated the documentary, later saying: &ldquoI never liked the idea of &lsquoRoyal Family&rsquo, I thought it was a rotten idea.Cameras followed the Royal Family around for a whole year, accompanying the Queen on tours (Image: BBC)&ldquoThe attention which had been brought upon one ever since one was a child, you just didn&rsquot need any more.In Netflix documentary &ldquoThe Royals, Ingrid Seward, royal editor described the Royal Family as celebrities, adding: &ldquoThey&rsquore our Hollywood.The narrator explains how the Queen came to the idea of having a reality show that would expose the Royal Family in all their glory.&ldquoKing George V saw the potential of radio in the 1930s to reach the people and delivered the first royal broadcast, the narrator adds.Queen making small-talk with former U.S. President Richard Nixon (Image: BBC)&ldquoSo did Elizabeth II, in 1969 when she allowed a television documentary to be made about the private lives of the royals.Anne Sebba, Wallis Simpson&rsquos Biographer explains: &ldquoThis was completely revolutionary, to go into their homes to see them having breakfast, having meals, to recognise them as an ordinary family.&ldquoOne of the reasons why it hasn&rsquot actually be shown before, is because they were too ordinary.&ldquoIf you take some of the glamour away, then your taking away from why the Royal Family is so special, It was compulsive viewing.The documentary was considered a public relations success (Image: BBC)But some were horrified to discover intimate details which showed the Queen following trends of every day people.It is understood some of the personal aspects that horrified viewers at the time would be seen as trivial today.The Queen and her advisers then &ldquorealised that being too normal was as dangerous as being too different, according to the Smithsonian Channel which recently uploaded a clip from the documentary on YouTube.The documentary was considered a public relations success.However, even though it was a huge achievement, the Queen reportedly ordered it to be put away in a vault and it has never been seen in its entirety since then.

You have to see the alternatives and then ask: is what we have a basis?The German Chancellor added she was happy both sides had finally&nbspagreed to&nbspa deal after &ldquolong and really not easy negotiations, but the EU&rsquos 27 member states would still have to assess the draft before it could give its full assent.Mrs May&rsquos future came under scrutiny this week after the chair of the European Research Group, Jacob Rees-Mogg announced the Prime Minister&rsquos deal was &ldquonot Brexit and revealed he had issued a letter of no confidence in the Conservative Party leader.For the Tories to be able to trigger a leadership contest, 15&nbsppercent&nbspof MPs would need to write letters demanding a confidence vote to the chairman of the party&rsquos 1922 Committee, Sir Graham Brady. The number of 48 letters is yet to be reached.On Thursday evening the Prime Minister delivered a press conference at Number 10 Downing Street on Thursday afternoon to defend her draft proposal, adding that her plan throughout the negotiations has been to put the national interest first.She said: Leadership is about taking the right decisions, not the easy ones. I believe this is a deal which does deliver that, which is in the national interest, and am I going to see this through? Yes.On Friday afternoon former Health and Social Care Minister Steve Barclay was appointed as the new Brexit Secretary replacing Dominic Raab.Before Mr Barclay was appointed, Environment Secretary Michael Gove reportedly ruled out the position as he wanted to re-negotiate the terms of the draft Brexit deal agreed by the EU and UK this week.

Therefore I look forward to campaigning with John in favour of staying in the EU because, let&rsquos be clear, it&rsquos taken Theresa May two and a half years, and many circumnavigations around the globe, in order to get to the position we&rsquore in today, with this fiendishly complicated agreement she signed this week.I think she&rsquos done best of a bad job but what she has tested to distraction is this idea you can leave the European Union but keep all the benefits. story: European Union leaders have been broadly united in their support for the draft deal the Prime Minister has struck with Brussels amid mounting concern Britain could tumble out of the bloc without an agreement when it officially leaves on March 29, 2019. But the German Chancellor, seen as one of the most prominent voices among EU leaders, has been particularly vocal over Britain&rsquos Brexit negotiations this week. She warned a no-deal Brexit could be the &ldquoworst and most chaotic scenario but was clear in her reluctance to concede more ground to London if any further Brexit negotiations are required.                Brexit BETRAYAL: Angela Merkel's role in David Cameron calling EU vote                EU leaders giving us even more reasons to leave, says LEO McKINSTRYSpeaking after a cabinet meeting in Potsdam, Germany, Angela Merkel said: We have a document on the table that Britain and the EU 27 have agreed to, so for me there is no question at the moment whether we negotiate further.&ldquoYou have to see the alternatives and then ask: is what we have a basis?The German Chancellor added she was happy both sides had finally agreed a deal after &ldquolong and really not easy negotiations, but the EU&rsquos 237 member states would still have to assess the draft before it could give its full assent. This could happen at a specially arranged summit in Brussels scheduled for November 25.READ MORE: BREXIT LATEST NEWS - LIVE UPDATESBrexit news: Angela Merkel has dismissed hope of further concessions on Theresa May's Brexit deal (Image: EPA  )But that has been thrown into serious doubt following a chaotic day for Theresa May, which saw her face leadership challenges, letters of no confidence and resignations from Cabinet, including Brexit Secretary Dominic Raab - all furious at the proposed deal.Mrs Merkel&rsquos latest intervention comes after several other EU figureheads warned the deal is &ldquothe best we can do and there is no room for further compromises.A senior EU official responsible for Brexit negotiations echoed Mrs Merkel&rsquos warning, and said: &ldquoOn both sides we&rsquove exhausted our margin of manoeuvre under our respective mandates.&ldquoAs negotiators we&rsquore happy to stand over the agreement. We think it&rsquos the best we can do collectively.&ldquoIf someone comes with wishes for changes they have to take their responsibilities and assess what that does to the process.                Farage THANKS Merkel 'failure' for helping get Brexit 'over the line'                Merkel BLAMED for helping Brexit and handing 'painful' blow to GermanyBrexit news: Guy Verhofstadt said there is not a lot of room for manoeuvre (Image: )EU Brexit coordinator Guy Verhofstadt added: &ldquoThere is not a lot of room for manoeuvre to say, &lsquoOK, let&rsquos start again&rsquo.Following the chaotic day for Mrs May yesterday, European Council President Donald Tusk described the deal struck between the two parties as &ldquodamage control but did appear to offer some hope to the Prime Minister over a possible reversal on the terms.She said: &ldquoIt is not for me to comment on the latest developments in London.&ldquoAll I can say is that the EU is prepared for a final deal with the UK in November.&ldquoWe are also prepared for a no deal scenario, but of course we are best prepared for a no Brexit scenario.Brexit news: Donald Tsuk (right) described the deal agreed as damage control (Image: )Mrs Merkel&rsquos latest comments came just 24 hours after she described Brexit as a &ldquodeep wound in the side of the EU during a speech in the European Parliament on Tuesday.The German Chancellor said: The United Kingdom is a country that is soon leaving, this is a deep wound.She then praised Brussels negotiator Michel Barnier, adding: We can all applaud him for the work he has done.Mrs Merkel warned MEPs that the EU's values are being challenged by populists across the entire Continent.She said: We are seeing our values called into question.

title: tory mp penny mordaunt drops her fella
story: Portsmouth MP and Naval reservist Penny Mordaunt, , shot to fame after stripping down to appear on cheesy ITV ing show Splash! and turning the Commons air blue with naughty jokes.But now it’s emerged she’s broken up with long-term partner Ian Lyon who breeds Burmese cats.The part-time opera singer also ran an IT company and was elected onto the city’s council last year as a Tory councillor.The true blue couple reportedly had eight cats, but no children.A pal of the pair told The Sun: “It’s just one of those things that came to the natural end, there was no one  involved.”As a Brexit-backing rising star, Ms Mordaunt is now one of Westminster’s most eligible bachelorettes.She was a key figure in the Vote Leave campaign, but is best known for her belly flopping out of Tom Daley’s Saturday night ing show Splash! in .She gave away the £, appearance fee, with £, is going towards the renovation of her local lido.The rest was given to four Forces charities.She was appointed Minister of State for Disabled People, Work and Health in Theresa May’s reshuffle in July.The daughter of a former paratrooper she was named after the navy frigate HMS Penelope.The former Armed Forces Minister is an active Royal Naval Reservist, serving as an sub-lieutenant at HMS King Alfred on Whale Island near her Hampshire constituency.She hit the headlines in  after revealing she had said “c***” in a Commons speech several times as part of dare.It came in a debate on poultry welfare to fulfil a bet set by her Royal Navy colleagues.Explaining the gags, Ms Mordaunt said: “When I was at Dartmouth doing my reservist training some of my marine training officers thought it would be a good idea to try and break the ladylike persona that I maintained throughout the whole of my course by getting me to yell particular rude words during the most gruelling part of our training, and I’m happy to say that they failed in that.”She added: “But during our mess dinner at the end of the course I was fined for a misdemeanour, and the fine was to say a particular word, the abbreviation of cockerel, several times during a speech on the floor of the House of Commons and mention all of the officer’s names present.”Ms Mordaunt was was previously married in  to Paul Murray, who she met when studying at Reading University.Wed at , the pair split shortly after and she later told told friends the experience left her so bruised that she never wished to marry again.Ms Mordaunt declined to comment.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: theresa may cabinet resignations 2018
story: In the wake of a spate of resignations over her proposed Brexit plan, the Prime Minister will need to make drastic changes to her team.A reshuffle is an informal term for the PM switching around jobs in the Cabinet.Ministers can be moved between departments or booted to the back benches as the head of Government decides on her new team.Reshuffles are common following elections, high profile resignations, deaths or retirements and also in the wake of bad press.Mrs Mays Government was thrown into disarray after several minsters said they could not support her soft Brexit plans.The most recent Cabinet reshuffle took place on July  after David Davis resigned as Brexit Secretary.He was replaced by Dominic Raab, another Leave supporter, who later also resigned after the PM revealed her proposed Brexit deal.

title: apprentice airline best episode years
story: It split apart million years ago and, must confess, it had entirely escaped my notice before Wednesday night — when it became the fourth-worst ever suggestion for the name of an airline, behind Black Box, Crash Positions and Ryanair.Or it was until Sabrina, from team Collaborative, came up with something that was worse than all of them — Jet Pop Airlines — and added a little explosion in the logo, just to set passengers’ minds fully at rest.No one involved should beat themselves up over any of these decisions, though, as they helped create the best episode of The Apprentice in years.It probably needed to be, as well. I sense, like the recently axed Big Brother and The X Factor, it’s been living off its reputation for a couple of years.Enjoyable as it’s been, the basic issue with this run has been the lack of a central figure in the mould of Syed Ahmed, Katie Hopkins or the late, great Stuart Baggs to take the series by the scruff of the neck.Some have shown vague promise but the closest thing it’s had to an alpha bell-end is Captain Pangea himself, Kurran Pooni, who was marked out less by his all-round uselessness than by the wrist he broke arm-wrestling back at the house, and his insistence he was “ per cent stepping up as project manager” just before he  per cent stepped down.There was no dodging the bullet, though, last week, when Lord Sugar demanded he PM a marketing campaign “for a noo airline” with accompanying adverts “and a noo unorm as well”.Kurran wasn’t underselling the sense of destiny he felt at this responsibility. “Everything in my le has led to this moment,” he claimed, presumably ’cos he hadn’t done anything  up until that moment.The great thing about this task, though — like all the best Apprentice episodes — was that the laughs were shared round equally.So while advert director Kurran was recreating the Club Tropicana video on Southend seafront, Camilla and Jackie were designing a stewardess’s unorm for the party-themed Jet Pop that wouldn’t see the light of day eveneasyJet suddenly opened a brothel chain in Amsterdam.A horrible thought occurred, though, as she was market-researching at Heathrow.She’s not going to wear that thing pitching to  industry experts at BA HQ, is she  She bloody is, you know.She gave it the full doors-to-manual flirtation as well. So everyone’s mind was already in the gutter before Jackie finished the audience off with the news: “It’s very easy to wipe down, as well.”In the normal course of events, reducing Claude Littner to a helpless giggling wreck would be enough to lose any task.The other team, though, Typhoon, had contrived to come up with something almost as bad, Manage Air, a business-targeted operation whose corporate logo looked like a satanic pentangle and theme tune was AC DC’s Highway To Hell.There was a genuine sense of tension in the boardroom then, which would’ve been ruinedSugar had played it all for laughs.He didn’t, though. He let the contestants hang themselves with their own words before firing Kurran, who could leave with a sense of “job done”.He’s created a bit of Apprentice folklore, after all, and hopefully reminded everyone this show is far from dead.Naturally, in the final taxi scene, he also remained convinced of his genius, boldly declaring: “My advert was gold.”The first and possibly last time in his le where he’s not just  per cent wrong, he’s  per cent right as well.Glorious television.Dianne: “Stephen Fry.”The Time It Takes, Joe Lycett: “Sesame Street’s Big Bird lives in what street ”Oliver: “I don’t know.”Joe Lycett: “A bird in the hand is worth two in the what ”Jon: “Foot.”And Bradley Walsh: “Which former EastEnders star presents the Sky One series Extreme World ”Zoe: “Barbara Windsor.”CELEBRITY Hunted contestant and former Commando Johnny Mercer MP has faced a stark choice this past month.The eternal humiliation of being beaten by Chris and Kem, off Love Island, on the Channel  hide ’n’ seek game.Or two weeks in a confined space with a clearly smitten Kay Burley.Heroically, he chose the latter, enduring her attention and pet namewith the same sort of grit that probably saw him through three tours of Afghanistan.Then, last week, he sneaked off for an unscheduled visit to his we, Felicity, and Burley completely lost her s***.Lost it so badly, in fact, that she threw herself at the mercy of a passing bread truck driver, which led to the best update of the series: “Kay Burley is currently in a -ton lorry, on the M, between junction  and .”She was quickly grassed up, of course, then apprehended at the Warburton’s depot, without the need for a vet or a tranquilliser dart.But while it’s a poorer show without the old mad-whack, there’s still plenty of mileage left in this gripping series.AJ Pritchard is cornered in Shropshire, Olympic silver medallist Louis Smith has just been found hiding in his mate’s Jacuzzi showroomand Baldrick-brained duo Chris  Kemhave somehow given everyone the slip.But as for Johnny Mercer  He’s probably smuggling himself back to the Mouth of Hell fort, in southern Helmand, just for the relative peace and quiet. Paul Merson: “For me it’s six and a half of one and a dozen of the other.”Graeme Souness: “The only one with potential is Martial and Pogba.”Dion Dublin: “Liverpool are in second and a half gear.”And Charlie Nicholas: “Pogba’s either brilliant or a showpony. He played OK last week.”THIS week’s Doctor Who episode introduced us to the Demons Of The Punjab, who turned out to be nothing of the sort.They were just morbid sods who mope around the universe “honouring those who die alone”, like soldiers, holy men and Brendan O’Carroll on For Facts Sakes.No actual science-fiction storyline to speak of then.But that’s not really the point of this viewer-shedding series, which has already got on its high horse about sexism, Donald Trump, American segregationist racism, men giving birth and gun control.Kind of inevitable, then, that the BBC would eventually pour a bucket of its self-loathing sick all over the British Empire, via the partition of India in , with an episode that was every bit as historically powerful as Carry On Up The Khyber.The key dference, of course, was that Bungdit Din and his Burpers weren’t actually being used as a means of brainwashing children.Because If you were expecting Doctor Who to present the flip side of Britain’s relatively benign rule in India , then you’ll also be waiting for the episode where Jodie Whittaker lands in a Soviet gulag and starts teaching children about the brutal idiocy of Marxism.The BBC just doesn’t do anything other than its own left-of-centre view, these days – or irony by the sounds of things.As it’s just been revealed there’ll be no festive episode of Doctor Whobecause it’s “run out” of storylines.Run out  RUN OUT How the hell can a series run out of ideas when it hasn’t had any yet This Morning, Thursday: “Coming up, at quarter to , the rise of the penis filler, Doctor Ranj is here to answer your questions.”The show’s other penis filler, Martin Lewis, will answer them on Monday.IT seems almost wrong to single out just one programme from Sunday’s beautul Armistice Day coverage, but the year’s most meaningful TV awards should probably all go to BBC’s They Shall Not Grow Old, made by Peter Jackson, whose astonishing film gave a voice, laughter, tears and colour to some of the extraordinary men who survived the - trenches.Those of us who watched it, on Sunday, are unlikely ever to forget the experience. Those of you who didn’t, must catch up with it on the BBC iPlayer.Be sure, though, to watch it right through to the credits’ last chorus of Mademoiselle From Armentières, where it names the veterans who have all long since passed but whose memories and souls have never seemed more alive and unforgettable.“It’s quite hard to put your finger on it.”I’ll bet.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: martin lewis free financial education textbook
story: Well, no, actually. It’s far more important than that. Money is an issue of wellbeing.Financial problems are one of the biggest contributors to orce, mental health issues, losing the roof over your head, custody of children and even suicide. And our nation has a real problem with financial capability.That’s why I passionately believe all our children should have financial education at school. While some may say it’s the parents’ responsibility, that doesn’t work when so many parents are struggling to understand financial issues themselves.In , I was involved in leading the successful campaign to get financial education on the English national curriculum, split across Maths and Personal, Social, Health and Economic education .It hasn’t made much dference. The Government put no resources into it.So we kept campaigning. Last year the Government said it would love to see a textbook, but couldn’t or wouldn’t fund it.So I made a donation to cover all costs to the Young Money charity. And last week, , free copies of the first curriculum-mapped financial education textbook Your Money Matters was sent to every English state school .It covers saving, budgeting, borrowing, working, tax, student finance, risk and reward, security and fraud and a lot more. It’s also available as a free PDF.I’ve been surprised at how many grown-ups have downloaded it to go through it with their kids, but ended up telling me they’ve learned something too.Companies spend billions advertising, marketing and teaching their staff to sell, yet we don’t get ANY buyers’ training. That is as pathetic as it is typical.The French themselves spend only . per cent.We’re second only to the Americans in our spending — but even then I would argue that it’s not enough.Our Armed Forces have been cut to the bone over the past two decades.Would we be able to retake the Falkland Islands now,Argentina invaded  I doubt it.The truth is that Nato is the one alliance of which we should be glad to be a member.It is an alliance of largely civilised, largely democratic countries which has held fast against tyrants, despots and warmongers for  years.Most notably, of course, the Cold War, in which the Soviet Union was defeated without a shot being fired.But now Trump is getting a bit tired of Nato because the US always has to spend, spend, spend.And with the Europeans thinking again of having an EU army there are many who think the days of Nato are numbered.That would be a terrible mistake.An EU army to replace Nato It would be bureau­cratic, incompetent and short-funded.And it would surrender before you could say “Macron”.THE Lord Mayor of Sheffield is a ludicrous dingbat called Magid Magid who has been coughed up from somewhere deep in the bowels of the Green Party.Shortly before Remembrance Day he posted a publicity shot of himself online wearing a white poppy and a T-shirt saying “never again!”A good moment, then, to ask the vital question: Have you ever met someone wearing a white poppy who wasn’t a complete and utter moron We wear red poppies to commemorate the terrible loss of le in battle.People wear white poppies to commemorate themselves and their fatuous sensibilities.It’s called showing off.WAGES have risen at the fastest rate for almost a decade.They went up by nearly three per cent in the three months to September, compared to a year earlier – and about time, too. This has been the real problem with our economy.But it looks like we’re on the right track.UH-OH – the Beast from the East is said to be on its way back.You remember late last winter. We were snowed in for a week. Nobody could come to visit.The missus couldn’t get to the shops to buy anything.It was just about perfect. All you need is a few bottles of Jack Daniel’s and some soup. Make sure you’re prepared.LUCKY, lucky earthquake victims.Here’s Paris Hilton in Mexico, visiting survivors of the  earthquake.And giving them bottles of Paris Hilton perfume and cushions with “Paris Hilton” stamped across them.Just exactly what they needed.Paris said: “I love the people, I think they are all beautul, they have great hearts, they are beautul inside and out, they are very genuine and incredible.”Just like you, Paris, just like you. A WOMAN who met the Liberal Democrat peer Lord Lester says she was offered an interesting proposition.Have sex with me, the -year-old goat suggested, and I’ll make you a baroness.Can’t say fairer than that, can you The most I’ve ever offered is a bag of Pickled Onion Monster Munch.Lester has been suspended from the House of Lords as a result.Thing is, it’s always the liberals who get up to this kind of stuff.Harvey Weinstein, Kevin Spacey, Woody Allen and now Lester.Ladies, I’m telling you,a liberal bloke approaches you in a bar telling you how pro-feminist he is, activate your alarm, call the Old Bill and get the hell out, sharpish.THIS is Sophie Michelle. She makes £k a year by whispering to people over the internet.Usually stuff like: “Hello sweetheart.”She says it stimulates the listener’s “autonomous sensory meridian response”.Which is perhaps the longest phrase for “penis” I have ever heard.MONICA LEWIN­SKY was the young intern who had an affair with President Clinton, back in the s.Come on – you remember. According to reports a cigar was involved.And Monica had a revealing stain on the front of her dress.She’s been talking about the whole episode again.And she says she thought the stuff on her dress was “spinach dip”.Really  If it looked like spinach dip I think Bill should have got himself off to a doctor, pronto.Are you sure it wasn’t cock-a-leekie ASIA BIBI is the Pakistani Christian woman who was sentenced to death for alleged “blasphemy” against the Prophet Muhammad.She then had her sentence commuted and some Pakistani Muslims are going bonkers, as usual.Demanding she have her head cut off. Threatening to kill anyone who supports her.We should give the poor woman asylum in our country, away from the Islamist savages in Pakistan.But the Government fears “reprisal” attacks by the extremists.That’s a gutless response and devoid of ­principle.Give Asia Bibi a home here. We’ll deal with the savagesthey try ­anything on.We’re getting used to it, after all.I’M trying to work out which of the Remoaners I dislike more. Gary Lineker or Tony Blair.I suppose Gary didn’t illegally invade a sovereign country.But then Blair never sported a stupid goatee beard or spent half of his le selling crisps.Although I daresay he would have donethere’d been enough dosh in it.Lineker, like many other remoaners, was demanding a second vote on Brexit. A People’s Vote.Yep, we’ll do that.Just as soon as we can replay football matches because I don’t like the original score.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brexit deal purgatory leavers remainers
story: It’s quite a challenge, but let’s have a go.Suppose, for the sake of argument, that Britain ended up with all the costs and obligations of European Union membership, but with no voice, no vote and no veto.Suppose we had to accept all the EU’s rules — on technical standards, on environmental protection, on labour law — but no longer had any say over what those rules should be. Suppose we had to submit to a trade and tarf regime designed solely to benefit the other .I hope both sides could agree that such an outcome would be the worst of all possible worlds. And yet, that is where we appear to have ended up.First, under the transition, we shall explicitly be non-voting members for two years.As Brussels has spelt out with brutal clarity, the only change will be that Britain loses its Commissioner, its MEPs and its vote in Council.Then, under the backstop, that status, or something very like it, will be imposed on us in semi-perpetuity.Surely no one — Remain or Leave — can favour such an outcome.I have been arguing since polling day for moderation.I was prepared to accept any compromise, including European Free Trade Association and including Chequers, provided it restored the supremacy of our laws.But the purgatory that now beckons is surely, by any definition, worse than either staying or leaving.From the start, our objective was simply to reach a deal — any deal.Our negotiators, shell-shocked by the referendum result, approached the talks in a spirit of damage limitation.They never seriously contemplated walking away, and the other side smelt their desperation.To be fair, our officials were not helped by the noises coming out of Westminster.How would you expect EU negotiators to react when senior British politicians urge them to hang tough and force a second referendum We might view Tony Blair, John Major and Nick Clegg as has-beens but, believe me, they are seen in Brussels as men of influence.So we fell into a pattern. Britain would make some new concession in the hope of unlocking a deal.Then Brussels would pocket the concession and demand more and — incredibly — British Remainers would cheer.The UK agreed to hand over more money than was due accepted the EU’s absurd and illogical sequencing made an unconditional security guarantee offered to copy EU standards and promised not to be more competitive than its neighbours.Each time, the EU brusquely demanded “more movement”. Each time, Britain rushed to comply.Which brings us to where we are — facing colonial rule from Brussels, of the sort the EU imposed on Bosnia following the Yugoslav war.I am not one of those Brexiteers who half-favoured no deal all along.On the contrary, I was proposing moderation even before the vote, and have repeated that call many times since.But, paradoxically, our reluctance to countenance no deal has made such an outcome likelier.We have reached the point where the terms on offer are less attractive than either a World Trade Organization-based Brexit or a second referendum. This last point is critical.I suspect that two contradictory arguments will now be wheeled out before wavering MPs.Europhiles will be told that the deal, backstop and all, is better than “crashing out” on WTO terms.Conversely, Eurosceptics will be told thatthey don’t approve the deal, Parliament might vote to extend Article , thus imperilling Brexit.These two lines of argument can’t both be true, of course and, in reality, neither of them is.We’re invited to believe thatBoris Johnson and Jo Johnson, from opposite ends of the Brexit spectrum, both oppose the deal, it can’t be too bad. In fact, both Johnsons oppose it because it is a lamentable failure of statecraft.Boris was no Brexit headbanger: He came out for Leave only after the EU refused to give David Cameron any powers back.And Jo is no Remoaner: He has spent two years in Government trying to deliver a reasonable Brexit. If neither of them will back the deal, that tells us something.There is still time — just — to recover our position.As things stand, the backstop has no legal force.The moment it finds its way into a treaty, it will be binding. If any MPs oppose the current approach, now is their chance to act. There won’t be another.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: time for decades of eu lies to end
story: Britain is a eurosceptic nation. In the s, Ted Heath and Harold Wilson both knew we would baulk at belonging to a Common Market that robbed us of our national independence.So they hid its true purpose — “ever closer union”, leading to a superstate with one currency. The public was reassured our sovereignty would not be surrendered to any meaningful degree.The Tory and Labour leaders both knew this was a lie. But they kept quiet when signing us up in  and when holding the first referendum in .Voters were betrayed from the start. And the pattern was set.In  John Major signed the Maastricht Treaty, creating the EU, without risking the public vote that saw it initially rejected by the Danes and Irish.In  Tony Blair — who now shamelessly praises fork-tongued civil ­servants for hoodwinking eurosceptic ministers — feared he would lose a referendum on handing new powers to the EU. So he refused to hold it.His successor Gordon Brown, never big on honesty when a lie served him better, pretended this Lisbon Treaty was too insignicant to bother voters with.The EU is founded on deceit. “When it becomes serious, you have to lie,” says President Jean-Claude Juncker. Voters are bullied into reversing inconvenient referendums or denied a say at all.And so to Mrs May, the Brexit deal her Cabinet agreed last night and the revealing EU leak yesterday which makes crystal-clear Brussels’ intentions to keep us in its vice-like grip for ever.That plan being to lock us into its Customs Union for all time, unable to make our own trade deals, powerlessly swallowing its orders and obeying its rules.Our Government knows we cannot legally escape this central pillar of the EU — which we voted to “leave”, remember — without consent from Brussels that it will never give.This is not some minor afterthought, to be bargained away, which is why MPs rejected it in July. It is crucial to the reclaiming of our sovereignty which a .million majority including many Sun readers, voted for in .It is crucial to our post-Brexit prosperity. It looks crucial, too, to whether the deal lives or dies. Yet, knowing exactly what the EU intends for us, the PM still brazenly insisted yesterday that we WILL make our own trade deals.How, Mrs May  We cannot. You surely know it.Do not kid yourself no one is paying attention. The public has been sold a pup again and again. It has had enough.Come clean with Britain. This deal is not wholly without merit. But let us see it for what it is.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. For further details of our complaints policy and to make a complaint please click here.

title: family six move thirteen times four months
story: Dean and Amy Coombes were evicted from their house in St Austell, Cornwall, in June, leaving them and their four children - all aged under eight - without a home. The family have since had to live on campsites in a caravan, hotels and pubs all across England.Cornwall Council said it was supporting the family but unfortunately there is a high demand for temporary accommodation, which includes our own housing stock, properties that we rent, or other accommodation.Mr Coombes said they thought three times that their hell was over when they were told a permanent property had been found - only for the offer to be withdrawn time and time again.They say well give you a house and then the next day they say no we wont, Mr Coombes said.It feels like we are being strangled. Your hopes are up and then you are shot down again.We have run out of enthusiasm, added Mrs Coombes.We feel deflated - you want to throw the towel in. You want to give up but know you cant. The kids are the reason we havent given up.The family have had to put their belongings in storage.Mr Coombes said: We left one place in the morning, packed the car with all our bags, drove to St Austell and just waited in the car with the children.Then they rung us up and said we were booked back into the same campsite we had just left.Their child have also had to move schools as a result of the chaos.He said: We dont want much - just a bit of stability and normality for the kids.The kids are asking all of the time - they are confused and have been dragged from pillar to post. We feel guilty they are going through this.I dont want an extravagant house. I just want a place that is suitable for my family, kids and our dog. Im not asking for five acres of land and a swimming pool.Amy added: We feel let down as a family.Its been very stressful for the children - they are struggling to cope with it. Its not fair on them.Were adults - we can cope better than children.Dean said he just wanted stability.A three bedroom house is the minimum, he added. Four bedrooms would be great and five would be bliss.I look every day for private accommodation but they get snapped up. Its very stressful.Neither of us drink though Amy smokes a little.I am grateful for the accommodation weve had but it just feels like weve been failed by the council. Cornwall Council said: Unfortunately accommodation can be dficult to arrange, especially for larger families who have pets.We review the availability of accommodation on a weekly basis and will move families to a more suitable placeappropriate.There is a plan for the family to move in to a privately rented home however like any other move where more than one family is concerned we have to wait for the current tenants to move out before this family can move in.Polly Neate, CEO at housing charity Shelter, said: Hit by budget cuts and a lack of affordable homes, overstretched councils are struggling to keep homeless families within local communities.To put an end to this the government needs to ramp up efforts to build more social housing to give families the chance of a decent and permanent home.

title: ivf test parents pick kids intelligence
story: A new test has been created to identy embryos at risk of severely low intelligence, its emerged.It raises the debate around designer babies yet again, and suggests parents could opt not to have less intelligent kids.The firm behind the test, Genomic Prediction, said it has started talks with several IVF clinics to provide it to customers, New Scientist reports.Bosses say the test will only be available where theres a risk of mental disability, but it raises the possibility of the same approach being used more widely in future.The firms co-founder Stephen Hsu, told New Scientist: I think people are going to demand it.If we dont do it, some other company will.The controversial test is currently only being considered in the US.Before it could be offered in the UK the test would have to be given the green light and licensed by the Human Fertilisation and Embryology Authority.The test gives parents risk scores for a range of conditions before their fertilised embryos are implanted back into the womb.It means they can pick embryos based on the risk of conditions like breast cancer and diabetes, which are affected by hundreds of genes.But its come under fire for the ability to screen embryos based on intelligence.While it cant predict an embryos exact IQ, the test can identy those at the extreme ends of the spectrum - giving parents the chance to avoid having a child with a IQ score lower than .Nathan Treff, Genomic Predictions chief scientic officer, said its just an extension of screening that is already used to identy embryos at risk of Downs syndrome.For complex disorders though we have to evaluate the entire genome in order to get the risk, he said.The very extreme end of risk, the opposite of intellectual ability, is intellectual disability.There is a potential to avoid that condition by selecting an embryo that does not have it.Screening embryos has been a part of the IVF process for years.But until now, tests have only been able to identy conditions affected by mutations of single genes.The new test gives scientists the ability to screen for conditions where lots of dferent genetic mutations are responsible.Ewan Birney, director of the European Bioinformatics Institute said he has concerns about the test.He told The Times there could be unintended consequences that scientists cannot yet predict.And he said a rigorous ethical debate would be needed before any such test was used in UK clinics.Meanwhile, Simon Fishel, president of Care Fertility, told The Times he believes the test is necessary.Its always about balancing the good versus the potential for bad, he said.When the first genetic screening was introduced for IVF, he said the same debate raged.Without a shadow of a doubt its been lesaving, he added.Cognitive disability is a health issue. Were not talking about whether we need to make more intelligent people in society.

story: And in our digital age, theres enough cameras around to snap a photo at just the right moment to capture a truly hilarious image.Sometimes, its a matter of being in the right place at the right time.But it can also be a question of having the kind of mind that notices strange coincidences and patterns in the world around you.And all over the globe, people delight social media users by sharing their perfectly-timed shots online.Heres a gallery of some of the best weird and wonderful flukes.

title: mum world worst parking firm mexico manchester airpoirt
story: Zoe Parr, , was shocked to find a £ fine from the supermarket - despite entrusting her car with a meet and greet parking company as she set off on her trip.The penalty notice was sent with a CCTV camera snapshot of a stranger driving into Asda in her BMW d M Sport on the second day of her holiday.The company, Manchester Airport Parking Services Ltd., was last month dubbed the worlds worst airport parking meet and greet and has been repeatedly accused of losing cars, as well as damaging a Range Rover in a collision with a bus.Mum-of-two Zoe, from Wolverhampton, said: Its completely unacceptable what they have done.They have been using it as a freebie because the petrol tank was empty when it ed to us.Its was absolutely appalling behaviour from a professional meet and greet car parking firm.For them to have taken the car out for their own personal use whilst we were on holiday is quite cheeky really.Asda has now dropped the fine, but the meet and greet parking company has still refused to apologise or refund her.Zoe and her new husband, who doesnt want to be named, jetted off from Manchester Airport on a two-week honeymoon break on July .They paid for a meet and greet service with Manchester Airport Parking Services Ltd, and Zoe made a note there was , miles on the clock.They chose the firm because the website boasted customers get a park happy experience with every stay, she said.But when she landed back in Manchester a fortnight later, she discovered there was an extra  miles on the clock, leaving the petrol tank virtually empty.When the man came to drop it off it suddenly, he just dropped the keys in my hand and dashed away rapidly, she said.That was when we got into the car and released that something isnt quite right.There were crumbs all over the back seat and the petrol light was on so I knew then that the car had been driven.Zoe said they gobsmacked at then being confronted with the fine from the Asda store in Oldham.She said they also contacted the police, but were told they could not prosecute because they dont know who the driver was at the time of it being in Asda.And she says she is yet to receive an explanation from the company - despite contacting them seven times.I have gone through hell trying to find out what happened to our car, its actually spoiled our honeymoon completely, said Zoe.I feel like I have been burgled because the police cannot do anything in taking action against this firm. The whole experience has been absolutely disgusting.Manchester Airport Car Parking Services has not responded to a request for comment.It comes after the firm was accused of losing cars and racking up speeding tickets over the past few years.One young family with a three-month-old baby claimed they were stranded for hours after the company allegedly crashed their car into a tree in June this year.While another couple claimed the same firm had lost their car and denied ever having it - until cops located it  days later.

title: ramzan kadyrov instagram kittens
story: However, behind this veneer lies an incredibly dangerous warlord with a notoriously fearsome reputation.The -year-old leader caused a stir this week after his Instagram account - which boasted .million followers before being blocked because of US sanctions - was reinstated briefly.He took the opportunity to post a poem about his favourite gun, before he was once again removed from the social media .Posing with baby animals including kittens, chicks and goats, Kadyrov displays his softer side online - a far cry from his fearsome dictator reputation, allegedly responsible for a whole host of kidnappings, assassinations and torture.Kadyrov rose to power in , appointed as leader of the Russian region by president Vladimir Putin to fill the role after his father’s death.Here, Sun Online reveals allegations of the much darker side to the cute cat pics and celebrity pals, looking at the controversial reality of the Chechen president’s le compared to his bizarre online persona.Pals with Putin and leader of the predominantly Muslim region in southern Russia, Kadyrov has aired some controversial views when it comes to the LGBTQ community.Ramzan caused international outrage after a wave of alleged state-sponsored violence against gay or bisexual men.According to reports, over  innocent men were rounded up and sent to detention centres, where they were beaten and tortured.Kadyrov denied LGBT people exist in his country, and said gay people should be sent abroad to pury our blood.When questioned about the alleged round-up, abduction and torture of gay men, Kadyrov replied: This is nonsense.Honour killings began after the authorities outed many men to their families.The president has strong views on women too - urging his fans to lock them up to stop them airing their views on certain topics.His strong comments came following criticism about the controversial marriage of a -year-old police chief to a -year-old girl, with some believing she was being forced into it.Kadyrov supported the match and described it as the wedding of the millennium, then instructed men to deny their wives the use of WhatsApp.He also said: “Lock them in, do not let them go out, and they will not post anything.“The family honour is the most important thing. Do not write such things. Men, do take your women out of WhatsApp.”Under Kadyrovs alleged ruthless regime, minor offences can mean major punishments.Possession of drugs is reportedly admonished with torture, beatings and disappearances.According to the Independent, Kadyrov is quoted as saying of drug users: “Shoot them, to hell with them. Nothing matters – the law, no law. Shoot them, do you understand ”A number of his critics and political opponents have reportedly been murdered over the years - something Kadyrov denies involvement in.In , human rights group Memorial named  detainees among  feared to have been secretly shot dead by police in Chechnya.The group claimed they had questioned Chechen officials for information on the missing men, but they refused to tell us whether they were dead or alive.Despite his fearsome reputation to those who cross him, Ramzan is seemingly generous to those in his favour.He recently gave a , white Mercedes Benz C to a five-year-old, an act which was later publicised on Instagram.In a move that clearly delighted Ramzan, Rahim Kurayev - dubbed the Chechen Schwarzenegger - did , push ups in two hours and  minutes.The youngster posted a series of photos of himself with the president, and his new sports car, to his , followers.The leader has also hosted a whole array of celebs and has some very famous connections, who are seemingly unfazed by his reputation.American boxer Floyd Mayweather stepped off his private jet in Grozny, Chechyna in  to be greeted by Kadyrov, and they recently went rle shooting.The president has also entertained actor Jean Claude Van Damme, reportedly watching a play together before having dinner.Oscar winning actress Hillary Swank attended his birthday in , which she apologised for after public outrage, admitting she hadnt been aware of his human rights record.Hes also spent time with the likes of football legend Ronaldinho, and Liz Hurley, who he met through her co-star Gerard Depardieu in , while filming out there.Despite his tyrant reputation, it seems Ramzan has a soft spot – for baby animals.His Instagram account was littered with images of the hardman posing with an array of animals, from kittens to goats and tiger cubs.In one, he can be seen next to Liz Hurley, who is clutching a tiny white kitten.He has had a menagerie of exotic pets over the years, including a pet tiger and lion.The lion was given to him as a present when his baby son was born in November .He was also reported to keep a bear, wolf and a number of fighting dogs, which are kept in one of his army bases.According to Russian news agencies, Kadyrov has one we, and  children – two of whom are adopted.He has said in the past that he believes men should be able to marry up to four women.He said: Allah gives permission to have four wives.We arent saying: take four wives, so the man takes them to the registrar and makes it official. But according to our religion, she is a legal we.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: dave advert public transport north south divide
story: And when it comes to the railways, even HS has no hope of uniting the ided regions - as was recently proved by an advert for TV channel Dave.The poster showed a tongue-in-cheek commuting decision flowchart which posed responses to the question: Should I try and start a conversation on the train An arrow helpfully leads to the only solution on the chart: No.And it managed to cause regional rts when a photo of the funny flowchart was shared on Reddit by user EchoesofDiscord with the caption: Take heed, northerners.Some northerners immediately lampooned the post as completely daft.Aptly named user BitterTyke wrote: Miserable buggers, Ill talk to me sen then.Another northerner said of the image: This is why southerners are the worst.But they were blasted: To be fair, you Northerners dont quite get it.You walk out of the door of your thatched cottage, shout hello to the milkman across the road, wave at Dobbin over the fence of his field, nod at Mrs Miggins as she sweeps the doorstep of her Pie Shop, walk round the corner and get to work at the farm mine steelworks .If I tried to talk to everyone I saw on my way to work Id have to give up by the station and turn round and go home because it would be gone lunchtime.Even people in the Midlands couldnt resist weighing in to the debate.Gazzlol wrote: Im not even northern, Im Midland scum, but Ive found southerners are generally ruder.But Snowzey argued: As a northerner who has spent the last five years living down south, its not southerners that are rude, its Londoners.

title: universal credit un wreaking havoc
story: In a damning new report, Philip Alston, the UN rapporteur on poverty, said the new flagship benefits system was ruining Brits mental health, finances and work prospects.After a probe into poverty in the UK, he said the Government was in denial about the impact of benefit cuts - and said that leaving the EU could make things even worse.Government policies have inflicted great misery unnecessarily on the working poor, single mothers, the disabled and children, he stormed.He said today: The government could solve this, the money is there, but they choose not to. He blasted ministers as in denial and dont see any problems.After taking a -day tour of the UK, the UN rep looked at Brexit, Universal Credit, cuts to local services and employment.But critics said he shouldnt be focusing on Britain - and should be looking at poverty in third world areas instead.The Australian professor went to Ireland in  too.Tory MPs insisted the plans were a waste of time and money because the UK is one of the richest countries in the world.But today he claimed that one FIFTH of Britain live in poverty - and .million are destitute and cannot afford basics.In a y report he concluded: British compassion for those who are suffering has been replaced by a punitive, mean-spirited, and often callous approach...As the country moves toward Brexit, the Government should adopt policies designed to ensure that the brunt of the resulting economic burden is not borne by its most vulnerable citizens.He was particularly damning about the new flagship benefits system, which roles six payments into one.It is fast falling into Universal Discredit, he said, saying the DWP were more interested in economic savings and sending messages about lestyles than genuinely helping people.Recipients are immediately plunged into further debt and inevitably struggle mightily to survive, he said.Many claimants also feel that they are forced to jump through hoops for the sake of it, fill out pointless job applications for positions that do not match their qualications, and take inappropriate low-paid, temporary work just to avoid debilitating sanctions.One Conservative Party MP with whom I spoke criticised DWP for adopting a military-style command and control approach.But the analysis was rejected by Conservative MPs.Philip Davies said: “If the UN are serious about tackling poverty they might want to go to the Third World. That would be a more valuable use of their time than coming here and grandstanding with some hard-left agenda.”Fellow Tory David Morris added: “Professor Alston has given no methodology to his conclusions. His job means he is permanently hunting on a poverty safari.”Hundreds of Brits have said they are struggling under the new system, and say they have been pushed in to debt for the long wait for payment. One in six Brits are still not getting their first benefits payment on time, new figures revealed this week.Mr Alston blasted the draconian sanctions regime for small errors and said the test and learn approach was treating vulnerable people like guinea pigs and wreak havoc in real peoples’ lives.The digital-focus of Universal Credit was a key part of that, he added, which fails highly vulnerable Brits.The hardest hit are women, children, people with disabilities and pensioners, Mr Alston said.John Dickie, the Director of the Child Poverty Action Groupin Scotland said today: The Rapporteur’s findings should be a wake-up call for government at every level.UK Ministers now need to wake up to the damage being wreaked and end the freeze on working age benefits, scrap the two child limit and fully restore the value of universal credit.But a Government spokesperson said: We completely disagree with this analysis. With this Government’s changes, household incomes have never been higher, income inequality has fallen, the number of children living in workless households is at a record low and there are now one million fewer people living in absolute poverty compared with .Universal Credit is supporting people into work faster, but we are listening to feedback and have made numerous improvements to the system including ensuring . million households will be up to £ better off a year as a result of raising the work allowance.We are absolutely committed to helping people improve their lives while providing the right support for those who need it.

title: 536ad worst year to live plague famine
story: Hard professor Michael McCormick said AD is a prime candidate for the unfortunate accolade of the worst year in the whole of recorded history.At the start of that year, the Middle East, Europe and some parts of Asia faced  months of complete darkness caused by a mysterious fog.It caused snowfall in China, continental-scale crop failure, extreme drought, famine and disease throughout most of the northern hemisphere, reported Daily Mail.The harsh year was caused by a cataclysmic Icelandic eruption, according to scientists.Archaeologist and medieval historian Prof McCormick told Science Magazine the world isnt thought to have recovered until AD - more than  years later.He said: “It was the beginning of one of the worst periods to be alive,not the worst year.”Effects on the climate were so severe that the records tell of “a failure of bread from the years –”.Temperatures in the summer of  fell to between .°C and .°C, making it the coldest decade in the past , years.Historians have long known that the middle of the sixth century was a particularly dark period in what used to be called the Dark Ages.But the source of the mysterious clouds has long been a puzzle.However, McCormick and glaciologist Paul Mayewski at the Climate Change Institute of The University of Maine believe they have figured it out.At a workshop at Hard this week, the team reported that a cataclysmic volcanic eruption in Iceland spewed ash across the Northern Hemisphere early in AD.After that, there were two other massive eruptions in  and .The repeated blows, followed by plague, plunged Europe into economic stagnation that lasted until AD.Volcanic activity is believed to have produced millions of tonnes of ash which spread over vast swathes of the world.Spikes in the ice core for lead proved smelting was taking place to create silver and this coincides with the advent of coin minting which helped revive the economy, according to archaeologist Christopher Loveluck of the University of Nottingham.Researchers found that a century later in AD the silver became the coinage of choice.

title: mum bus journey children give up seats oap
story: The woman explained on the British parenting forum Mumsnet how a woman in her sixties started moaning “loudly” because she wasn’t offered the seats by the mum’s two children, aged four and six.The mum-of-three claried that she was already standing with a baby in the pram and didn’t have a seat to offer to the woman.She gave further context to explain she always has her kids sit in a seat after her son had fallen on the same bus and banged his head on the floor while “standing up and holding on” a few months prior.Going by the username “whatsthepointthen”, she said the older woman kept “shaking her head” throughout the journey.It prompted the mum to pose this question: “Should children give up their seats for their elders ”The answers ied depending on the age of the child and how able-bodied the older person is.Other suggestions were to have the kids share a seat or to have them sit on the mother’s lap.One responder said: “It depends on who is more in need there are too many iables to say who should get the seat.“In your case I would have offered my own seat,you had one and were able to ride the bus safety.“I may also tell my children to share a seat.”Another added: “If they are young enoughyou sit them on your last so everyone can sit down.”One suggested that it depends on the health of the older person.They said: “It depends on the older person’s health.“If they clearly struggle to stand under ordinary circumstances then it is hard for them than it is harder for them than it is for your children and they should get the seat.“Butthey are just old with no obvious infirmity then I don’t see why anyone should give up a seat for them.”Another said it depends on safety of the bus route.They said: “If possible I would have had one on my knee, some bus routes are not suitable for small children to stand up on.”Other responses had little sympathy for the mum.One said: “The six year old should be standing. If he fell he obviously wasn’t holding on properly.”Another added: “I’d expect the six year old to stand for an older lady. That is just basic consideration.“Can your six year old ride a scooter  If so, he’s got a sense of balance ”

title: tom hardy buckingham palace cbe prince charles
story: The actor was snapped on the kids toy wearing a hoody, baseball cap and shorts as he sped around near his home yesterday.But he scrubbed up today in a smart navy suit and matching tie as he received a CBE from Charles.He teamed his dapper look with brogues and slicked back hair.The Venom star beamed with pride as he was handed the award for his contribution to cinema - starring in blockbusters such as The Dark Knight Rises, Dunkirk and Inception.Hardy also became an ambassador for The Princes Trust in  and is understood to have become close with Prince Harry - branding him a f***ing legend in a magazine interview.He also attended the Royals wedding to Meghan Markle earlier this year at Windsor Castle.Other stars receiving a gong today included footballer Jermain Defoe, who was handed an OBE for his services to his foundation.It was launched in  after a hurricane in St Lucia - the Caribbean island his grandparents came from.The Bournemouth star dedicated his award to his little friend Bradley Lowery, who died last year at age just six, due to a rare type of cancer.The pair touched the hearts of the nation when they struck up a close bond after football-mad Bradley was a mascot at his beloved Sunderland where Defoe was a striker.Defoe told Sky Sports: “It’s special, it’s just so surreal. Even in the palace I was stood there like, ‘wow is this really happening ’ Amazing, amazing feeling.“I’d love to dedicate this amazing day, this OBE to my little friend Bradley. Because, everyone knows the relationship I had with Bradley.“I got this for the Jermain Defoe Foundation, but I think above all of that I think it’s the relationship I had with Bradley.“You never expect to receive any award, so to receive something like this, of course it still hurts.“I’ve got some great memories of Bradley, but to receive something like this today, it makes me feel good.”Liverpool legend Sir Kenny Dalglish was given a knighthood by Prince Charles in recognition of an outstanding career on and off the pitch.The ace won three European Cups in seven years as a striker and as a manager earned top-flight league championship titles with Liverpool FC and Blackburn Rovers.He has also raised more than £million for charity work with his we Marina.TV historian Lucy Worsley, who is chief curator at Historic Royal Palaces, was awarded an OBE and entrepreneur Jo Malone was given a CBE for services to the British economy and the GREAT Britain campaign.

title: long cold winter space temperatures nasa
story: Thats the warning from a scientist who fears sunspot activity on the surface of our star has dropped so low that record low temperatures could soon set in.“We see a cooling trend,” says Martin Mlynczak of NASA’s Langley Research Center.“High above Earth’s surface, near the edge of space, our atmosphere is losing heat energy.If current trends continue, it could soon set a Space Age record for cold.”Solar minimum can enhance the effects of space weather, disrupt communications and navigation, and even cause space junk to hang around, NASA said.Mlynczak and his colleagues have recently introduced the Thermosphere Climate Index , which measure the how much heat nitric oxidemolecules are dumping into space.The results come from the SABER instrument onboard NASA’s TIMED satellite, that monitor infrared emissions from carbon dioxideand nitric oxide .By measuring the infrared glow of these molecules, SABER can assess the thermal state of gas at the very top of the atmosphere – a layer researchers call “the thermosphere.”When the thermosphere cools, it shrinks, making the radius of the Earths atmosphere smaller.This means it can delay the natural decay of space junk, resulting in a more cluttered environment around Earth.“Right now, it is very low indeed,” Mlynczak told Space Weather.“SABER is currently measuring  billion Watts of infrared power from NO. That’s  times smaller than we see during more active phases of the solar cycle.”“The thermosphere always cools off during Solar Minimum. It’s one of the most important ways the solar cycle affects our planet,” explains Mlynczak.“We’re not there quite yet,” he said of the record cold, “but it could happen in a matter of months.The most famous example of a prolonged sunspot minimum is the Maunder Minimum, referring to a period around  to  during which sunspots become exceedingly rare.Maunder coincided with the middle part of the Little Ice Age, when Europe and North America experienced colder temperatures - fuelling speculation that the two were connected.However, the prevailing hypothesis for the cause of the Little Ice Age is that it was the result of volcanic action - meaning that a decline in solar activity was not the main cause.

title: worst conditions landlords feral tenants
story: From a bath full of rubbish and an unknown black liquid, to festering toilets, peeling walls and junk-strewn gardens, homeowners have shared these snaps of the wreckage some renters have left behind.One picture shows a bathroom thick with layers of grime and paint peeling from its walls.Another image shows a kitchen stripped bare of any paint, wallpaper of flooring.The pictures have been shared with interior specialist Hillarys, which has launched a competition to find Britains worst tenants from hell.The company invited the nations landlords to upload photos of the worst conditions their tenants have left their homes in, with the most shocking in with a chance of winning £ - cash.

title: spice girls tickets cardiff resale price
story: The hotly-anticipated tickets in Cardf went on sale today at .am as Geri Halliwell, Emma Bunton, Mel C and Mel B added an extra date to the tour.Viagogo – an online market place for ticket resale - is currently flogging premium seated tickets in for £, - almost  times the face value of £..And premium Spice Circle standing tickets will set fans back £ compared to the £ face value cost.On StubHub, tickets for seating are being flogged for £. - five times the £. face value.While the same website is flogging seats in the upper tier for £., which is also five times the face value cost.It comes after Sun Online revealed some resale sites for selling tickets to see the Spice Girls for up to £, just minutes after they were released on November .Viagogo was flogging a VIP ticket to the show for £, instead of the £, which is what it costs at face value.While seating tickets, which ranged from £- £ originally are selling from £ - £,.Spice Girls fans were left frustrated as they struggled to get tickets and noticed the extravagant prices on resale sites.One upset punter wrote: “Well I sincerely hope @spicegirls bring out more dates because that was a joke. And £ for a £ standing ticket already on a resale site     #spicegirls.”Another ranted: “When is something gonna be done about ticket touts  like @viagogo   Its disgusting that so many fans are missing out #SpiceWorld #spicegirls.”While someone  moaned: “Trying to get spice girls tickets for the past hour and a half, my friend has been in the queue since am  How have we not got tickets “There needs to be a ban on ticketing touts! That is defiantly what has happened!”The group, who will go back on the road together next year without Victoria Beckham, will kick start their tour in Dublin on May .They will become the first girl group to headline Croke Park with tickets going on sale on November  at am.

title: statue of unity see space gujart india
story: The colossal Statue of Unity depicts the independence leader Sardar Vallabhbhai Patel and was recently unveiled standing at ft – twice the height of the Statue of Liberty which is ft tall.Satellite images have now been released which show it is visible from space.A clear shot of the Statue of Unity in Gujarat was captured from space by the commercial satellite network Planet.The image from the space clearly shows the structure towering over the Narmada River.The statue, which cost £million, has been controversial with questions raised about the price tag as well as its environmental impact.The heads of  villages around the Sardar Saro Dam where it is situated wrote an open letter to India’s nationalist prime minister Narendra Modi criticising the cost and environmental destruction caused by the statue.Modi unveiled the statue of one of the country’s heroes of the independence movement at the end of October and stands in Modi’s home state of Gujarat.In a promotional video, Modi said: This memorial to Sardar [Patel] is going to become a worldwide tourist attraction.See our height, measure this nations height. This is what we want.The Patel statue was built in  months, but not content with one giant statue, Mr Modi has already commissioned another of a warrior king in the state of Maharashtra, set to be ready by .Modi’s prediction the statue would be a huge tourist attraction appears to be coming true, so far.The Times of India reported that , people visited last Saturday.Narmada district Collector R S Ninama, while confirming that , tourists visited Saturday, said the administration was expecting visitor numbers to go even further up.

title: dominos new garlic pizza bread
story: The chain is set to unveil a new garlic bread pizza crust with the best combination of buttery garlic bread and pizza.The pizza giant said in a statement: “It’s the ultimate hybrid pizza garlic bread crust.A quirky pizza edge is not overly new — the hugely popular stuffed cheese option led the way, followed by other brand’s more experimental offerings from meat pie to cheese burger crusts.But outside of pizza, garlic bread is the most ordered menu item and the company expects the new crust to be a big seller.But Dominos said the new dish will not be coming to the UK in the near future.Domino’s Group CEO and Managing Director, Don Meij, said the summer menu launch Down Under was the brand’s biggest-ever initiative.New pizza toppings include BBQ steak and bacon, Korean BBQ steak, succulent garlic chicken and bacon ranch, and chipotle steak.There are three new sauces too as well as a handmade thickshake comprising watermelon and rose water with vanilla ice cream and Turkish delight pieces.Mr Meij said: “This summer Domino’s is looking forward to being a part of the unforgettable spirit of summer and giving Aussies the most delicious and biggest menu ever.Pizza is seriously big business in Australia and competition between outlets is intense.Last year, the Australian arm of the company — which also owns operations in New Zealand, Belgium, France, Japan and Germany — recorded total sales of . billionand a record profit of . million  up  per cent on the previous year.Domino’s sells a whopping two million menu items a week via its online and app ordering services alone.It has invested signicantly in new technologies, from its ordering and preparation systems to self-driving and automated delivery prototypes.This article originally appeared on news.au

title: amber rudd backs theresa may
story: The former Home Secretary had resigned on April  over the Windrush scandal of Commonwealth migrants wrongly deported.But The Sun has learned the PM was “determined” tothe -year-old to the front line to help fend off a Brexiteer coup.Ms Rudd is one of the most impassioned May loyalists on the Tory benches.However, the swt political resurrection also restores Ms Rudd as One Nation Tory moderates’ top candidate for party leaderthe PM is toppled in a confidence vote. That is expected next week.The comeback of the Hastings MP was the most eye-catching move in a swt reshuffle forced on Mrs May after seven resignations in protest at her soft Brexit deal.She replaces Esther McVey, who quit on Thursday after a bitter row with the PM during a five-hour Cabinet meeting on Wednesday to sign off the draft EU plan.The other vacant Cabinet post of Brexit Secretary was filled by Stephen Barclay, who had been a mid-ranking health minister.Ms Rudd’s first act in office was to mount a stinging attack on Mrs May’s seething Brexiteer critics for navel-gazing.Calling on the plotters to think again, Ms Rudd said: “This is not a time for changing our leader, it is a time for pulling together to remember who we are here to serve.“I worry sometimes that my colleagues are too concerned about the Westminster bubble rather than keeping their eye on what our job is.”Extolling Mrs May’s virtues, Ms Rudd added: “I am confident the Prime Minister can survive — I think she’s demonstrated this week her complete commitment to making sure that she serves the people she was elected to do so.”The combative Cabinet minister also praised Mrs May’s Brexit deal as “a really practical response to leaving the European Union” and “the right combination”.Her rapidwas made possible by an official report last month into the Windrush scandal which cleared her of blame.Ms Rudd now faces the titanic task of completing the introduction of Universal Credit, the new all-in-one benefit beset by delays and controversies.Little-known former solicitor Mr Barclay, , is a Brexiteer and May loyalist, and replaces Dominic Raab.But the job in charge of the Department for Exiting the European Union will now only preside over Brexit’s domestic delivery and No Deal preparations.The PM took full charge of the last ten days of EU orce negotiations.Mr Barclay is a close friend of Mrs May’s chief of staff Gavin Barwell, so is “unlikely to resign in a huff like the previous incumbents”, one senior Tory said.Environment Secretary Michael Gove had been offered the top Brexit job by Mrs May on Thursday but turned it down when she refused to let him go back to Brussels to reopen negotiations.Her radio humiliation came as  Conservative MP Greg Hands commented that the PMs cricketing idol was once deliberately run out by a member of his own side - Ian Botham - for the good of the team.Mr Hands wrote on Twitter: Interesting passage from Leo McKinstrys biography of Geoff Boycott when the England team had to run out their own captain for the benefit of the team. England went on to win by  runs.The PM told LBC: The thing about Geoff Boycott is he was absolutely steady, he kept there at the crease, he carried on and relentlessly went about his goal, and I think thats important.But host Nick Ferrari pointed out the England legend had been run out by Jim Love of Yorkshire in his last match.When he quipped Michael Gove might do the same to her premiership, Mrs May hit back: “I think Michael Gove is Scottish.Two troublemakers for No were also brought back into the fold as Mrs May tried to build bridges.Remain-backing EU rebel Stephen Hammond was made a health minister and Brexiteer John Penrose a Northern Ireland minister. Both were previously dumped.Leave campaigner Kwasi Kwarteng was promoted to fill a vacant slot in the Brexit ministry.Labour’s Shadow Minister for the Cabinet Office Jon Trickett called Ms Rudd’s appointment “a desperate choice by a weak Prime Minister”.THERESA May’s draft Brexit deal has split Tories.Here we probe the good and bad in it.End of free movement: The right to set our immigration rules at scheduled end of transition period in December .But EU will in future seek preferential treatment for its citizens infor a trade deal.Fishing: Regaining control of our waters, meaning more stock for our fishermen.But EU will later demand continued access to them infor access to its markets.Security: Continued exchange of DNA, passenger names and fingerprints plus car reg details.PM called it “beyond anything” agreed with any other country.Trade protection: We will be only major economy with zero trade tarfs and quotas.Close alignment to EU rules was necessary to avoid friction at borders and protect Car and aviation industries.Irish backstop: Insurance policy to avoid hard North-South borderwe cannot strike trade deal after transition.Entire UK would stay in customs union with the EU.Backstop exit: EU will have say on when we end backstop.Brexiteers fear we may never ditch customs union.European Court of Justice: During backstop its judges can rule on VAT, state aid, agriculture, customs rules and green policy.Longer transition: Planned December ,  deadline could be extended.It would see us keep paying Brussels.GOT a story  RING The Sun on    or WHATSAPP on  or EMAIL exclusive@the-sunOur journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes.
