title: stephen barclay brexit secretary theresa may twitter memes
story: The MP for North East Cambridgeshire was thrust into the Cabinet yesterday after Michael Gove turned the job down believing it was a poisoned chalice.The PM asked Stephen Barclay, the Leave-voting Health Minister, to take over from Dominic Raab as a leadership crisis swirled around her.But her choice left social media users baffled - with many posting memes asking who Mr Barclay is.One posted a GIF of Steven Coogan as Alan Partridge shrugging with the caption: Stephen Barclay Another shared an image from a goat waiting to be eaten by the T-rex in Jurassic Park, saying: Exclusive footage of new #Brexit Secretary Stephen Barclay on his first day at work.One posted a picture of Lenny from The Simpsons nervously sat in Mr Burns office with the caption: Sneak peek of Stephen Barclay on his first day on the job #BrexitSecretary.In a blow to Mr Barclay, Mrs May revealed the -year-old will be the next Brexit Secretary - but he wont be involved in talks with Brussels.STEPHEN Barclay is a Leave-backing MP who won the seat of North East Cambridgeshire in .Since then he has served as a Government whip, Treasury Minister and most recently Health Minister.Outside of politics he served in the military before working as a lawyer for the Financial Services Authority, and then - amusingly - at Barclays.Over the summer he warned that Britain mustnt lower any regulatory standards after Brexit.Mr Barclay takes over the top job from Dominic Raab, who quit earlier this week over Theresa Mays Brexit deal.He becomes the third Brexit Secretary in just four months, after David Davis threw in the towel in July.Hes married and has two kids.The role, previously one of the most powerful in the Cabinet, has been downgraded and will now only involve preparing Britain for our EU exit.His appointment also sent shockwaves through Westminster due to his previous low profile.He said this evening he was delighted to get the role and promised to keep up the momentum to finalise the deal and deliver a Brexit that works for the whole UK.The MP is believed to have landed the job because he is one of the few Brexit-voting ministers left in the Government.Elected to the Commons in , he was a minister in the Treasury for two years before becoming deputy to the Health Secretary in January.Environment Secretary Mr Gove was last night offered the Brexit Secretary job, but refused because he didnt want the responsibility of promoting Mrs Mays deal.The mini reshuffle also saw Amber Rudd brought back into the Cabinet - replacing Esther McVey as Work and Pensions Secretary.

title: lifting weights cardiovascular health advice
story: Both types of exercise improved key measures of cardiovascular health but weightlting was more effective.The muscle-building exercises led to more reductions in body weight and blood pressure and fewer incidences of diabetes.But neither forms of activity improved the amount of artery-clogging fats in the blood, such as cholesterol.It suggests elderly Brits could get more benefit from carrying heavy shopping bags home on the bus than going for a brisk walk.Researchers from St George’s University, in Grenada, analysed the health data and exercise habits of , adults.They found % of those aged  to  engaged in “static” exercises and % in “dynamic” exercises, such as running.The figures for adults aged  and older were % and %, respectively.Engaging in either type of activity lowered cardiovascular risk factors by % to % but the link was strongest in static exercises and in the young.Among the older adults, weightlting lowered blood pressure, body mass index and diabetes but not cholesterol.Activities such as running or cycling only reduced their BMI – but not by as much.Among the younger adults, weightlting lowered body mass index and diabetes only. Dynamic exercises lowered BMI but by a lesser amount.Public Health England suggests  minutes of moderate intensity exercise five days a week and muscle-strengthening exercises twice a week.Study leader Dr Maia Smith said: “Both strength training and aerobic activity appeared to be heart healthy, even in small amounts, at the population level.“However, static activity appeared more beneficial than dynamic, and patients who did both types of physical activity fared better than patients who simply increased the level of one type of activity.“One interesting takeaway was that both static and dynamic activity were almost as popular in older people as younger.“I believe this gives clinicians the opportunity to counsel their older patients that they will fit into the gym or the road race just fine.“The important thing is to make sure they are engaging in physical activity.”The findings were presented at the American College of Cardiology Latin American Conference in Lima, Peru. Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: ibiza party bars clubs shut up down
story: Ibiza tourist chiefs in Sant Antoni, also known as San Antonio, say they are fed-up with businesses flouting the new rules which require proper soundproofing and adherence to decibel levels, including closing doors and windows after midnight.They say while the situation has got a little better over the last summer, the noise problem is still very bad and inspectors will be going out and about to check which clubs, bars and restaurants are complying.Those that arent will be warned, fined and eventually closed down in a bid to improve the image of the resort and protect residents.The Special Acoustic Protection Zone already affects the party strip known as West End but is now being extended to take in the busy Calle de la Mar which is lined with nightspots.The businesses were all given six months to cut their noise limits and put in soundproofing but many have failed to do so.Those that have say it is unfair that others are still getting away with it.The Mayor of Sant Antoni, Josep Tur said tests were carried out in six streets over three consecutive weeks.While the results were an improvement on , the desirable effect had not been achieved.The council wants to get the decibel levels down to dB but in the majority of cases, the noise level was very bad at more than  decibels.In one particular street, highs of  decibels were recorded every day of the three weeks.Conversation in a restaurant, office, background music or an air conditioning unit at ft is  decibels.Councillor for the interior, Aída Alcaraz said this summer, the Local Police has filed  noise complaints,  of them in the West, against clubs which had left their doors open against the rules.The courts had also dismissed objections from businesses about the new regulations, ruling that the general interest prevails over the economic interests of the entrepreneurs.Sant Antoni council says many people have blamed the noise levels on the thousands of tourists as they leave pubs and clubs at closing time but this is not the case.Their tests had shown the noise was consistently bad at any time in the evening, not necessarily at throwing out time.

title: move junk food health advice obesity
story: They claim placing chocolate, crisps and doughnuts in high-profile areas encourages people to buy more and is fuelling the obesity crisis.But critics warn it will not be long before junk food is treated like fags and porn mags and only sold over the counter or from top shelves.The Obesity Health Alliance, which represents charities and medical groups, found % of food and drink in these areas was high in fat, sugar or salt.And their survey of Asda, Morrisons, Sainsbury’s and Tesco stores revealed an average of just % was healthier fruit and vegetables.Public Health England guidelines suggest eating five portions of fruit and veg a day, which should make up over a third of our diet.More than one in three children leaves primary school too fat, increasing their risk of cancer, type- diabetes, and heart disease in later le.The Government is expected to launch a consultation on the promotion and placement of junk food as part of its Childhood Obesity Strategy.Caroline Cerny, from the Obesity Health Alliance, said: “Where products are located in shops influences how likely we are to purchase them.“Sugary treats prominently displayed at checkouts or store entrances will be highly tempting to anyone, but especially children who will then likely pester their parents to buy them.“Action is needed to create healthier environments for families across the country.“Some supermarkets seem to be taking positive steps to limit where they promote unhealthy food but we need a level playing field.“The OHA is calling on Government to restrict the placement of unhealthy food and drinks in high profile locations in supermarkets to help families make healthier choices when shopping”.Bryony Sinclair, from the World Cancer Research Fund, said: “Displaying sugary food and drinks in prominent positions is unacceptable.“These powerful promotions tempt shoppers to make unhealthy last-minute decisions.“Many of these food and drinks contain more sugar than the daily recommended amount for a young child.“Eating too much sugar can lead to weight gain, and being overweight or obese increases the risk of  dferent types of cancer.“Governments need to introduce policies that prevent supermarkets from promoting unhealthy food and drinks in prominent positions, in order to help create environments that support healthier choices.”Christopher Snowdon, from the Institute of Economic Affairs, said: “People want to buy a iety of goods in a supermarket and popular items should be conveniently placed.“It won’t be long before Mars Bars are treated like cigarettes, hidden behind screens and only available to buy over the counter.“And pizzas will be treated like porn mags, placed on the top shelf, out of reach and out of sight of ‘vulnerable’ youngsters.” Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: michael gove cabinet pizza agreement theresa may brexit
story: The pivotal Environment Secretary was seen to have held Theresa May’s political fate in his hands as he agonised for  hours over quitting.But despite pleas from even his closest friends to resign and lead the bid to topple the PM, he decided it would be “irresponsible to walk out now”.Instead, Mr Gove will ally with four other Brexiteer Cabinet members to lead a seven-day race against time to enforce a vision of a Canada-style trade deal from the EU.Europe’s  leaders meet next Sunday November  to formally approve a declaration of future aspirations alongside the already nailed-down orce deal.Hardline Brexiteer ministers were horried when they saw “deep regulatory and customs cooperation” on goods as the basis for a blueprint agreed by the PM with Brussels.They fear that will tie Britian to EU rules forever and prevent major new trade deals being signed with countries such as the US.Other Cabinet members of the ‘Pizza Club’ – who meet secretly to discuss tactics are Commons Leader Andrea Leadsom, International Trade Secretary Liam Fox, Development Secretary Penny Mordaunt and Transport Secretary Chris Grayling.All four also independently decided to stay in the Government, thinking they would have more influence there, a Cabinet source said.But Mr Gove and the others have now given up hope of winning changes to the controversial Irish backstop, that could keep the UK in a customs union for years.The Cabinet source said: “May has made clear that she won’t allow the backstop to be unpicked, so Michael and the others will now wait to seeit falls at the meaningful vote.“But the political declaration on the future trade deal can be improved, as that’s still being negotiated right up to the summit. That’s where they feel they can have real effect now.”But The Sun can also reveal that Mr Gove told the PM her soft Brexit deal will be rejected by the Commons in a crucial showdown meaningful vote next month when he turned down her offer of Brexit Secretary on Thursday.The Pizza Club could meet as early as Sunday.They are also reaching out to other Cabinet ministers who have expressed unhappiness as the PM’s vision of close alignment to the EU - Liz Truss, Jeremy Hunt, Geoffrey Cox, and Sajid Javid.The Sun can reveal that Mr Gove’s former advisor and Leave campaign svengali Dominic Cummings went to his West London house on Thursday to heap pressure on him to resign.But another friend of Mr Gove’s said he felt he was “screwed either way”, as he didn’t want to be blamed by the party for bringing down Mrs May after kning Boris Johnson during the Tory leadership contest two years ago.Returning to work yesterday to reveal he was staying on, Mr Gove said he “absolutely” does still have confidence in Mrs May as leader.But he stopped short of publicly endorsing her Brexit deal.Signalling his plan, Mr Gove added: “I think it’s absolutely vital that we focus on getting the right deal in the future and making sure that in the areas that matter so much to the British people, we can get a good outcome”.Meanwhile Mrs May carried on with her desperate push to sell her Brexit deal to voters and MPs.Doing a breakfast show phone-in with LBC radio station on Friday, she insisted there were “areas where we said no, and held our ground, and the European Union has given in to us”.She added: “As you might recall, Ken Clarke did say I was a bloody dficult woman”.Liam Fox also issued his first words of backing for the PM after  hours of silence, insisting: “What we need now is stability”.But as the new boss of No Deal planning, he may have the most important job in Government.Onlywe’re ready for a clean break from Brussels is there a chance that the Prime Minister’s dodgy deal might be improved — and get through Parliament.Over the past two years of circuitous negotiations, the one lesson has been that the European Union understands only the most brutal, blunt language.British negotiators have tried the give-and-take compromise approach and the only result has been their pockets being turned out before they’ve got back on the Eurostar.We must now be clear that we are not just prepared to leave without a deal but will embrace doing so. That means Mr Barclay needs to get our ports, our airports, our security services and our customs authorities ready for March .Chancellor Philip Hammond must be clear, too, that he will use the £billion earmarked for the “orce bill” for a massive programme of infrastructure spending and tax cuts that will supercharge the economy. We must be bold.Theresa May has been clear that this is a “draft” deal. In truth Brussels will not change a single word unless we show them that we’re not scared of building a future outside the EU.The sorry deal we have is the direct result of unimaginative civil servants who viewed the vote to leave — the largest democratic mandate this country has ever seen — not as an opportunity to build a better future but as a damage-limitation exercise.It is telling that the PM, with remarkable resilience, has to do her own cheerleading. Where are all those in the Cabinet who back the deal  Why aren’t they on the TV and the radio It’s hard to shake the feeling that some still around the table are thinking too much about their career prospects at this vital time, hoping nobody will remember their silence.We hope the Brexiteers in the Cabinet, sidelined for too long, DO redraw this plan. They are, after all, now armed with the fact that as it stands it will struggle to get through Parliament. We hope that the Prime Minister WILL tell the EU they need to bend.But they will only listenwe ready ourselves to walk away and be ruthless.The PM’s unofficial deputy told the Cabinet this week not to get too hung up on the exit mechanism, that parliament could always find a way.It was pointed out that,needed, we could suspend the Ministerial Code and break international lawthe national interest required it.We shouldn’t take such a step lightly.But we are in extraordinary times, and perhaps only extraordinary action will do.Issuing an appeal to fellow Brexiteer Tory MPs to end their coup attempt on Mrs May, the Cabinet minister urged them to take “a rational and reasonable view” of the crisis.Dr Fox added: “We are not elected to do what we want. We are elected to do what’s in the national interest. Ultimately I hope that across Parliament we’ll recognise that a deal is better than no deal.”More than  business leaders have urged Tory MPs to vote down the draft Brexit plan. The group, including Wetherspoons’ Tim Martin, called it a “national humiliation”.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: pm should stand down after brexit james forsyth
story: A sizeable number of her own MPs will vote against it and her Northern Irish allies, the DUP, will reject it too.EvenMrs May could persuade  Labour MPs to back her, an optimistic assumption, that still would not be enough to get this over the line.So what can she do to change the dynamic  Well, she needs to try to separate the question of what the country should DO NOW from how she has handled Brexit since entering Downing Street.Mrs May has made some huge mistakes in her handling of Britain’s departure from the EU. There has been little preparation made for leaving without a deal, weakening the UK’s negotiating hand and sending a message to the EU that we’ll never walk away.She triggered Article  without knowing what she wanted, then wasted months and months of valuable negotiating time in internal discussions. She signed up to a joint report on the Irish border without telling her Cabinet how that would limit the UK’s options and end up shaping the entire negotiations.Even in recent weeks, she has made mistakes — making it patently obvious to the EU how much of a hurry she was in to get a deal and not letting her own Brexit Secretary seehe could winkle any concessions out of the EU. Given all this, it is not surprising that so many Brexiteers want to vote down her deal.But the question of how Mrs May has handled Brexit so far is NOT THE SAME as the issue of what Parliament should do given where we are now. There is ONLY ONE WAY for Mrs May to break this link.She should say that as soon as the withdrawal legislation is through the Commons, she will stand down as Prime Minister.  This would enable MPs to vote for the deal without that being an endorsement of her handling of Brexit or an invitation for her to negotiate the next stage of Brexit, the UK EU trade deal.One Cabinet minister tells me the PM is now an impediment to this deal passing. Her announcing her departure would make it easier for MPs to vote for the deal.Mrs May’s allies dismiss this idea out of hand. But she needs to do somethingshe is not to see her deal voted down, increasing — as she herself says — the chances of either no deal or no Brexit, both of which would be bad for the country.In Wednesday’s marathon Cabinet meeting, one of Attorney General Geoffrey Cox’s arguments for accepting the deal was that it would be possible for the UK to claw things back in the second half, the actual UK EU trade negotiations.But as any football fan will tell you, a team trailing badly at half-time doesn’t change things round by simply sending the same team in the same formation back on to the pitch.Would Liverpool have come back from - down to win the Champions League in they hadn’t changed anything at the interval  No.  If things really are to be dferent in the second half of these talks, then the UK will need new leadership.Now the problem is that some of these arrangements create an ongoing obligation under international law. So, getting out of all of them unilaterally would involve breaking international law. This would, arguably, be in breach of the ministerial code which requires them to “comply with the law”.But, I understand, it was pointed out at the meeting that the PMhas the power to suspend the ministerial code when necessary.This means the Government could simply get out of the backstop, then dare the EU to take it to court“LOYALTY is a two-way street,” one Cabinet minister told me after Dominic Raab resigned. This minister pointed out that Raab had been cut out of the negotiations so couldn’t be expected to go along with the result of them.David Davis resigned as Brexit Secretary because his advice was ignored. Michael Gove wouldn’t take the job because it came with no real power.Mrs May has appointed a new Brexit Secretary, Steve Barclay. But No are saying he will only be responsible for no-deal planning and the Parliamentary side of the job. He won’t be negotiating.He will also, as a Brexiteer, be sent out to defend this deal. He will be a “flak jacket to go out on TV”, one Leaver tells me.SPECULATION is swirling in Westminster about whether Mrs May will face a vote of no confidence or not in the next week.Several Cabinet Ministers are resigned to a vote happening. Others worry that the vote is ill-timed, that in going for her now the plotters won’t win but will instead ensure she stays on as Prime Minister for another  months and takes charge of the UK EU trade negotiations.A minister complains: “If we strike and miss now, we’ll be shackled to a corpse for a year and Corbyn really will get in.” Butthe rebels do get their  letters, Mrs May might have a harder time in the confidence vote than expected – though she will still win it.Several ministers admit that, in the privacy of the ballot box, they will vote against her.Our journalists strive for accuracy but on occasion we make mistakes. title: brian reade david camerons tory
story: NewsopinionBrian Reade: David Cameron’s Tory party is now humiliated and broken thanks to himWith the layers of Brexit lies peeling away, the public anger towards the man who gambled all our futures in the arrogant belief he could solve the Tory right’s obsession with Europe, is mountingShareCommentsByBrian Reade:,  NOV NewsopinionCameron marched us into the Brexit battle then scarpered "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailYou may have picked up on the big Westminster saga this week that left millions in despair and shamed the country. Yes, Jeremy Corbyn’s coat. Or as every right-wing bile-spiller called the raincoat he wore over his suit, on a rainy day, at the Cenotaph “a cheap and scruffy anorak which insulted our fallen heroes”. Well,Michael Foot can earn his stripes as a commie spy and a Remembrance Day tramp, why not Corbyn  The row rumbled on until Thursday when, despite the Tories cack-handedly ripping themselves to shreds and trying to drive the country they vow unending love to over the Dover clfs, a leading columnist in The Times penned a diatribe about the man in the “pound MS hooded raincoat”. As though most men in Britain would view a pound coat as cheap. Behind Corbyn at the Cenotaph, Tony Blair showed the way of a true patriot by wearing an expensive black, woollen coat which matched his expensive tan and sombre expression. That’s showing proper respect you see.  You may be directly responsible for sending hundreds of young men and women to their deaths in a futile, shyarguably illegal war, but at least you know what coat to wear when you’re remembering those pointless deaths. David Cameron was no slouching private either. He stood to attention beside Blair in a black Savile Row number, doing his country proud as he did when he marched us into battle against the Brexit he created, then deserted the second that battle was lost. Lest we forget. This brave chap has always known that it ain’t what principles you wear but the way that you wear them. It’s been bred into him. Remember when he told Corbyn in the Commons as he struggled to defend his party’s wilful destruction of the NHS: “My mother would say... put on a proper suit, do up your tie and sing the national anthem.”  It was the classic upper-class shypatrician retort when cornered. Look down on a man’s clothing and question his patriotism. But as Cameron’s party, like his country, now lies broken and humiliated thanks to him, who can he look down on  Whose patriotism can he question  With the layers of Brexit lies peeling away, the public anger towards the man who gambled all our futures in the arrogant belief he could solve the Tory right’s obsession with Europe, is mounting. Rarely is his name spoken without Danny Dyer’s accurate four-letter description of him thrown in.  Social media never tires of repeating shyCameron’s infamous tweet at the  General Election: “Britain faces a simple and inescapable choice – stability and strong Government with me, or chaos with Ed Miliband.” Even the usually mild-mannered Lord Melvyn Bragg has branded him “contemptible” and “a wimp” and asked “who the f*** does he think he is ” I think Cameron now knows who he is. Someone who believed he was born to achieve the impossible and be hailed the greatest Tory leader since Thatcher. But whose reckless vanity managed to achieve a dferent kind of impossible. Becoming the most despised Prime Minister since her. And I really hope, at the Cenotaph, that Tony Blair hugged him close to his black designer coat and thanked him from the bottom of his heart for that.

title: here your brexit traitors its
story: NewsopinionHere are your Brexit traitors - and its not Theresa MayThe real enemies of the people are the ones who arent doing their jobsShareCommentsByFleet Street FoxColumnist:,  NOV Newsopinion"Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailTwo years ago, the nation split in two on whether to have a massive constitutional upheaval. The wound has not healed. Every time we come together briefly, be it Royal weddings, bad weather, strikes or other reasons to rekindle the Blitz spirit, someone comes along to rip the sutures out. Any medic will tell you that an injury left untended for two years will attract flies and disease. The patient will pick at it, and people will be repelled by the odour. And so the schism in the British soul - and Brexit makes us all wonder what being British means, what it is for, andit will last longer than our letimes - has drawn opaquely-funded think tanks, millionaires of questionable finances, friends of Boris and organisms who would have long ago witheredthey did not have this flesh to feast on. John Redwood, a man we thought destroyed in  by his inability to sing the Welsh national anthem, lurched to le yesterday to claim Britain should ignore all legal obligations and debts owed to foreign states and spend the money on itself, with no thought for what that might mean for the debts we are owed by others. Alongside him were other backbench leforms often scratched at but rarely bothered with - Kate Hoey, Peter Bone, Andrew Bridgen, Dennis Skinner, Philip Davies. These are the ones who can be relied on to denounce pretty much anything.  Its the ones who think about what theyre doing, though, who are the biggest worry. Boris Johnson, who broods and plots and composes manestos that are all about Boris. Michael Gove, who wants the world to know hes spent  hours considering his position as though hes the real power behind any throne. And Jacob Rees-Mogg, who clutches his cufflinks while delivering the verdict of medieval autocracy on abortion, incest, and why the Irish need to be put in their place. They appear to actively seek a chaos which will destroy those poorer and less shouty than they are. These are the men who demanded a cake called Brexit, insisted the ingredients were available and method quite clear, but saw no need to check the cupboards or the cookbook. They tied the Prime Ministers hands, stuck a kne in her face and then demanded she ice it, too.  On the Opposition benches are  MPs supposed to offer an alternative to this Tory cannibalism but instead concentrating on how to get a Labour government. Plan A appears to be do nothing, which has the merit of not being dficult but has not, in the  years since they began it, achieved anything beyond nothing. All of these people are prepared to go on TV, into Prime Ministers Questions, and call press conferences to denounce, demand and decry a -page document many of them have not bothered to properly read. If they had, they would not act so surprised, as it is in essence the same draft agreement presented at Chequers four months ago. This threatens the union of our four nations! they complain. This is not what people voted for! BBC interpreter sums how the nation is feeling on Brexit Well, precisely. The fact Brexit heralds the break-up of the United Kingdom, renews the threat of terrorism in Northern Ireland and that the ballot paper was lacking in detail is sort of the problem.And of course this is not what people voted for - because THIS IS NOT THE DEAL. Its just a proposed agreement with the EU to allow us to talk about a deal for another decade, while pretending weve left the EU quicker than is logically possible. But these people who think carefully about their position, who take to the airwaves and send out their friends talking about vassal states and betrayals and a botched deal know this. They know its not the deal, they know it is temporary, and more importantly they know YOU didnt read the  pages either.And it is not as though, for all their talk of changing the Prime Minister, anyone  wants the job.  The Tories want to depose their leader, but have no one who wants to succeed her. They talk about letters that arent written and threats that are never fulfilled, and theyve been performing the same psychodrama for  years without ever once reaching the third act. Labour want to gain power because they believe theyre the good guys, but actually dont because they have no idea what to do about the Brexit cake someone  promised to bake. Corbyns current plan is to tell the EU, which is ready to negotiate a deal, that he doesnt want to, and go back and re-negotiate the transition instead. Meanwhile, the people are wondering where the cake is. They are told the recipes been botched, that the chefs hopeless, half the kitchen assistants have resigned, and the waiting staff are all militant communists. And theres an Irishman sitting in the corner getting angry. What should the British do, in such a restaurant  Half of us sit quietly and hope some sort of cake will arrive eventually, and that it wont kill us outright. And the other half huff, say they never wanted any bloody cake anyway, and vow never to be seduced by such offers again.  And nothings fixed. Families are arguing, the Tories are dying, Labour is withering, businesses are leaving, the pound is crashing. Theresa May has no power, but no escape route either - she has no choice but to limp on, like Jesus carrying his own cross to Caly, and will no doubt have to nail herself to it before anyone decides to end her misery. With her or without her, there is no Brexit agreement the Tories could agree on. There is no alternative Labour is prepared to offer. There is no way to overturn a democratic referendum, yet without a resolution it is inevitable this festering injury will kill us. Were like a couple whose most boring, habitual bicker has propelled them to the brink of orce, and are now wishing theyd never made such a thing of it. Whatever way we look, there is nothing but consequences. If we are to heal there is only one logical, British alternative. We must put politics, teams, tribes, Leave, Remain, his, hers, yours and mine, completely aside.  We need what we always do in times of crisis, a government of national unity to rule in Britains best interest, which is to never talk about any of this ever again. No-one gets to call anyone  a loser. Everyone can say they won. We just decide wed rather be together, and that were all going to be on our best behaviour from now on because harmony is not something to be reckless with. No-one voted to lose Northern Ireland. No-one voted for more Tory warfare. No-one wanted a useless Opposition, people resigning after not doing their job properly and blaming someone  for it, a female PM being beaten up every day by public schoolboys, or an EU that appeared to be more sane and reasonable than us. I love you. Lets never mention Brexit again.

title: ros wynne jones un envoy
story: NewsopinionInside austerity-hit Jaywick where girls on their period are so poor they Sellotape toilet paper into their underwearJaywick, which regularly tops the list of ‘most deprived’ parts of the UK, is well used to being the poster child for povertyShareCommentsByRos Wynne JonesReal Britain columnist:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsopinionDaily Mirror Reporter Ros Wynne-Jones on Austin Avenue, Jaywick "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailIt’s a sunny day in Jaywick and people are walking along the shyseafront and chatting at their front doors. By lunchtime, there’s already a buzz around the tiny Essex village. Unlike generations of politicians, a United Nations investigator, Philip Alston, is making time to visit during a tour of the UK to shyinvestigate the emergence of ‘extreme poverty’. Today, he delivered his report to a disintegrating UK government what he’s made of the harrowing stories he has been hearing across the country. I hope Alston told ministers about Rob, a nurse, who developed a serious health condition and found himself assessed by “people who barely have a health qualication” and was found ‘fit for work’. Have you got a personal story like this about austerity Britain  Email webnews@mirror  “In January I applied for ESA,” Rob told the UN man. “It took them seven weeks to tell me they had never received the form. I had to live on handouts. Going to a foodbank, it really does make you feel worthless.” And I hope Alston told them about a young disabled woman called Mollie who described “watching poverty crippling my mother”. And Rebecca who spoke about the “hostile environment” of zero-hours work. And a young woman called Raven who spoke up about “girls with toilet paper Sellotaped into their underwear” during their period. Jaywick, which regularly tops the list of ‘most deprived’ parts of the UK, is well used to being the poster child for poverty. A few days ago, a picture of one of its streets – Austin Avenue – was used on an attack advert by the Republican party in the United States. “They’ve no right,” Doris Telford, , a retired advocate for elderly people says. “They’ve never even been here.” Scott Michael, , nods. “We’re fed up of people saying we’re a shanty town,” he says. “We’re a community.”  A tenant of one of the houses in the picture asks not to be identied. “I didn’t have a choice about moving here,” she says. “The council moved me out of London because of the benefit cap. It’s a good enough place but the houses are falling down.” Built when motoring was in its infancy, Jaywick’s streets are named after cars, and the street plan was designed to look like a car grille. In the s, newly mobile families were able to get to the seaside at weekends, and a shyproperty developer had the idea of selling them land to build chalets on.  During the postwar housing crisis people started moving to Jaywick permanently. Now, decades on, many of these originally shytemporary homes are desperately patched up, or in dereliction, but local spirit remains strong. Even the village’s one pub is called the Never Say Die. Today, at the Community Centre, built on what was once the boating lake, most of Jaywick has squeezed in to see Mr Alston, the man from the UN, and to hear searing testimonies organised by Unite Community.  One man, called Steve, tells Alston he and his we had both been made redundant by the job centre. “The debts just kept racking up,” he says. “We were relying on foodbanks. We could just about afford to feed the kids, but we were missing meals. I felt I needed to provide, as a man, and I couldn’t do it. I didn’t realise how bad it had affected me. “In January , I contemplated taking my own le. I thought no one will miss me, I’m useless. I’m just going to end it.” When he tried to get help he was told he could only have telephone counselling. Another speaker, Trisha, tried to take her own le after getting pound, into debt. She’d worked her whole le for the NHS but left with spinal problems. Help from Christians Against Poverty made her realise “I’ve got a lot to live for and a lot to offer”.  But she adds: “Now, my area has gone to Universal Credit and I’m struggling again. All the clothes I’ve got on now are from the British Heart Foundation. I was six weeks with no money coming in, living off baked beans.” She finishes sadly: “It’s a lonely world out there.” Wheelchair-user Erin’s family went from “a comfortable middle-class two-income household” to near destitution after she had a brain haemorrhage.  The family have found themselves excluded from the rental market because of insidious ‘no DSS’ rules. “So I am to be made homeless,” Erin says. “I don’t where I am going to be putting our -year-old child to bed. This is the hostility faced by disabled people under austerity. We’ve even lost the very human right of a home.” Alston is clearly moved by what he’s heard, and he reassures people their testimonies “are not going to be for nothing”.  At the end of the meeting, in carefully chosen words, he echoes one of the final speakers. “Mike says that ‘Austerity is a political choice not an economic necessity’. That’s right. Poverty is a choice. You can choose not to make people poor.” Outside, night has fallen, and opposite the Community Centre the boarded-up Mermaid Inn and the derelict Dolphin Diner are a reminder of what Jaywick once was and could be again, given a fair chance. Today, the world will hear from Alston. How bitterly ironic that while he’s been here one of the politicians most responsible for these stories – Esther McVey, the Secretary of State for Work and Pensions – has resigned. Not from shame, but because she now hopes to become Prime Minister.

She really doesn#xt want to answer that question - only saying she hopes MPs will think about their constituents.:Mikey SmithCuts to police numbers and the orce dealAnother caller asks about cuts to police numbers, and the rise in violent crime. Is it not time to reverse course Mrs May says one of the things we can do is give the Police extra powers, like those in the Offensive Weapons Bill going through parliament.But she says the reasons we see a rise in violent crime are #xCerse.#xD She says some of it is to do with drugs, and there#xs a new drug policy happening.And she insists #xCwe#xre putting more resources into the police force#xD.But she says it#xs a mistake to think the only way to sort out the problem is with money. On stop and search, she says it#xs a really effective tool, but it should only be used - but lawfully. Nobody should ever be stopped because of the colour of their skin.She admits there#xs #xCmore for us to do#xD on crime.And turning to the #xA billion orce deal with the EU, she says there was always going to be some money to pay, and we#xre a country who meets our obligations.:Mikey SmithWheres the £ million a week for the NHS The next caller works in the NHS. But that figure is #xCnot the one to focus on, now#xD, telling caller Max we #xCwon#xt be sending vast amounts of money to the EU#xD and will have more money to send to the NHS.She says the #xCkey thing for the NHS is that the government have set it as the number  spending priority.#xDShe claims there will be #xC#xA million more a week#xD.:Mikey SmithMedicines after BrexitA caller, who is disabled, asks for how long sick people will have to worry about getting their medicines after Brexit.Mrs May says the Department of Health is making #xCproper contingency#xD to ensure medicines can get through the border after Brexit.And she says her deal ensures drugs will continue to be available into the future, by working with the European Medicines Agency.She says she#xs #xCnot sure#xDreports Health Secretary Matt Hancock said people could diethere#xs no deal are true.But she says as a diabetic who uses drugs from Denmark, she#xs got a personal perspective on this issue.More OnBrexitConservative PartyPoliticsEuropean UnionTheresa MayDominic Raab MP

title: tory think tank unwittingly invited
story: NewsTory think tank unwittingly invited paedophile onto boat party with underage guestsEXCLUSIVE: The Adam Smith Institute is favoured by top Tory MPs including Jacob Rees-MoggShareByAlan Selby:,  NOV NewsRichard Neate was on board the boat, just months after he was sentenced "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid Email A Conservative think tank unwittingly invited a paedophile onto a boat party with underage revellers.Guests at the bash were left outraged after child porn hoarder Richard Neate was sighted on board, just months after he was sentenced.The -year-old was found with indecent images of children as young as six and had a video of a man having sex with a dog.But the Adam Smith Institute welcomed Neate aboard their annual invite-only cruise down the Thames past Parliament. The Institute insisted the party was for over s, but after guests claimed  year olds were aboard, admitted under s had been present.The libertarian think tank is favoured by top Tory MPs including Jacob Rees-Mogg. Neate has been pictured enjoying a night out with another Conservative MP who backs the group. None of these figures were present at the boat party, and none were aware of his crimes.One appalled partygoer said the paedophiles appearance came after a pal was banned from attending the same shindig for criticising the group publicly.She said: “It’s , and a think-tank lets men get away with being literally sex offenders, but not women who express dissatisfaction.”She added: “There were under s on the boat.”Neate walked free in October  with a three-year community order and  hours of unpaid work.He was put on the sex offenders’ register for five years after more than  videos and images were found on his computers.Neate, from Cambridge, was snared after police investigated a series of tweets he had sent knocked at his door.After searching his hard drives they found the horric abuse images.He told police he had been “running a business selling adult porn to other adults” but this had spiralled into him searching the dark web for images of child abuse.There were  of the worst category A “moving” images discovered by police, as well as  category B and eight category C pictures.Neate admitted performing sex acts while watching the material and said he was sexually interested in children about  years old.Judge David Farrell QC told Neate “You won’t be getting a second chance” after letting him stay in the community under close watch.He appeared at the ASI party less than a year into his punishment.Attendees at the July  invite-only party complained to officials that Neate had been allowed on-board.But bosses were silent, they said, and did not listen to their complaints.One said “Many guests, some who were underage, wanted something to be done then the ASI did nothing and ignored it”, adding they were “disgusting”.The shindig was the annual celebration for their The Next Generation group, an important social event for young conservatives.On its website the Institute brands it a “network for classical liberals and libertarians under the age of . It meets in Westminster most months of the year.”They add: “TNG events are a great way to meet like-minded people, learn more about libertarian ideas, and get involved with the work of the Adam Smith Institute.“In addition to its regular meetings, The Next Generation also hosts an annual summer party aboard a boat cruising down the Thames- an event which has become something of a Westminster institution.”Recent guests have included former MPs Liz Truss, Douglas Carswell and former Brexit minister David Davis.Matt Kilcoyne, head of communications at the Adam Smith Institute, said: “The Next Generation series of events is for those between the ages of  and  interested in the ideas of classical liberalism.The safety of attendees at our events is of the utmost importance.“Our boat party, held annually, was conducted with a company that operates a strict policy of photo ID for those under the age of .Thank you for bringing to our attention that someone under the age of licence could have attended.“Over  invitations were sent out from an bulk email list. Unfortunately due to plus ones being invited by guests it might have been possible someone boarded the boat that should not have done so.“Mr Neate was invited automatically as the invitation list was copied over from a previous year.We’ve made it clear to Mr Neate that he is not able to attend future events.”

title: who stephen barclay new brexit
story: NewsWho is Stephen Barclay  New Brexit Secretary youve never heard ofBritain has its third Brexit Secretary after a forced Cabinet reshuffle. This is Steve Barclays biography, profile, voting record - and why you wont know who he isShareCommentsByDan BloomOnline Political Editor:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsStephen Barclay now has the unenviable job of planning for No Deal Brexit "Get politics updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailThe UK has its third Brexit Secretary in a year and youve almost certainly never heard of him.Stephen Barclay was appointed by Theresa May after both previous holders of the job - David Davis and Dominic Raab - quit over her plans for Brexit .He will now have the job of planning for a disastrous No Deal BrexitTheresa Mays plan falls apart by  March . So who is he, and why is he someone almost no one will recognise  Heres a quick guide.  Stephen Barclay - who calls himself Steve - is the -year-old MP for North East Cambridgeshire. The former Axa insurance lawyer and dad-of-two was born in , the son of a union official and civil servant, and grew up with three brothers who all played rugby. He went to pound,-a-year King Edward VII school in Lytham St Annes, Lancashire, and studied history at Cambridge. He spent his gap year in the army - serving with the Royal Regiment of Fusiliers.In perhaps the greatest ever case of nominative determinism, he was also a director at Barclays Bankbefore he became an MP. After trying and failing to join Parliament twice, as far back as , he was finally selected for his safe seat and won in . He was promoted to a government whip under David Cameron in  before rattling through junior ministerial jobs - first at the Treasury, then at the Department of Health. This is his first Cabinet job.  The MP was one of a string of government ministers who publicly said they would campaign to leave the EU. He said of David Camerons deal to remain in : “The deal does not deliver the game changer we need to protect against further EU integration.” That means all three Brexit Secretaries have backed Leave - seen as an important trait to hold the role. But hes not exactly a tub-thumping backer - hes only mentioned the word Brexit in Parliament  times.  Theresa May did try to recruit a more high-profile minister to the role, but struggled - because it meant finding someone who would go out to bat for her Brexit plan. Michael Gove reportedly turned down the job after saying hed only take ithe could renegotiate the -page deal, which Brexiteers say locks the UK under Brussels rules. With  Cabinet ministers reportedly slamming the deal in private - two of whom resigned - the Prime Minister was not exactly spoilt for choice for a new Brexit Secretary. The Prime Ministers spokesman said Mr Barclay was The Prime Ministers choice for the job, but declined to say whether any other MPs were approached to fill the role. Theresa Mays Cabinet has signed off a -page draft Brexit deal with Brussels - and it has enraged Tories. Here are some of the reasons why:The transition period can be extended - and we dont know how long for Goods face being checked between Northern Ireland and the rest of the UK We need the EUs permission to quit the backstop European courts will still have a big hold on the UKFOR THE FULL GUIDE CLICK HERE Not as much as you might think. When Dominic Raab was hired earlier this year he was denied the job of actually negotiating the deal. Instead that was led by the Prime Minister herself and her chief civil servant on Brexit, Olly Robbins. What will happen is hell be left to pick up the pieces - quite literally. His job will include planning for No Deal.  Just months after the global financial crash, in February , he spoke out against new regulation of the City saying it would deter investment. He said those backing it were trying to deal with events that only happen once in a letime. He voted in favour of gay marriage in  and against a backbench Bill to legalise assisted dying in . He voted in favour of slashing disability benefit Employment and Support Allowance by pound a week in . He voted in favour of UK airstrikes against Islamic State in Syria in . And he backed the bedroom tax despite asking for pound,. in accommodation expenses, we reported in . Theresa May has a Brexit deal, but the danger is looming that it will be defeated in the House of Commons. Even getting it past her Cabinet forced Esther McVey and Dominic Raab to resign. Now she faces two more hurdles - an EU summit with  leaders on November , and then the vote in Parliament at some point before Christmas. MPs are grouped in several factions - their warring opinions are explained more fully here. But or more vote against the deal, they will defeat the deal. Against the deal TORY BREXITEERS: There are up to  , led by Boris Johnson and Jacob Rees-Mogg. They will vote down a deal that keeps Britain trapped in vassalage with Brussels. TORY HARD REMAINERS: Only about a dozen, but many - including Justine Greening and Jo Johnson - will vote against, instead wanting a second referendum. DUP: Theresa Mays Northern Irish allies - who she handed pound.bn - are -strong. They will vote down the dealit allows customs checks between Ulster and Britain. LABOUR LOYALISTS: About  MPs are consistently loyal to Jeremy Corbyn on Brexit. The party has confirmed theyll be told to vote against the deal because it doesnt meet Labours six tests. LABOUR REMAINERS: There are about  hard Remainer Labour MPs. Theyre likely to oppose the deal to avoid enabling a Brexit.OTHERS: The SNP , Lib Dems , Plaid Cymruand Greensare all likely to vote against. For the deal TORY LOYALISTS: Well over  are likely to vote with Theresa May, for the deal. Many have paid government jobs - so would have to quitthey oppose her. NERVOUS LABOUR: Some Labour MPs could BACK a deal - fearing otherwise Britain will be plunged into an even worse No Deal. There could be  or more. Caroline Flint is among them. UnknownLABOUR BREXITEERS: There are only about half a dozen. It was generally thought theyd side with Theresa May, but Kate Hoey MP broke ranks and said she could vote against.

title: cage bed tragic toddler ellie
story: NewsCage bed where tragic toddler Ellie-May was tied up and left to dieEllie-May Minshull Coyles leless body was found in her Frozen-themed bed, which had been made into a cage, at Lauren Coyle and Reece Hitchcotts flat in PrestonShareCommentsByElaine McCahill:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video pair-sentenced-following-caged-toddlers-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPictures have been released of the horric Frozen-themed cage bed where a toddler was tied face down and eventually died. Lauren Coyle and Reece Hitchcott, both , were found guilty of causing or allowing the death of -month-old Ellie-May Minshull Coyle following a trial, but cleared of her manslaughter. They were each sentenced to  years in prison at Liverpool Crown Court today. Photographs of the bed show slats and sides from her cot had been attached to it with towels and sheets draped over them so the child could not see or get out. The little girl had been forcibly tied to the bed on more than one occasion and restraint marks on her body showed she had had at least one wrist and one ankle tied.  A post-mortem examination found her death was caused by forcible restraint by ligatures in a face down position complicated by hyperthermia. The prosecution said the duvet placed over the tot would have impacted on her ability to control her body temperature, causing her immense suffering, distress and upset. At some point on March , , the little girl stopped breathing and her heart stopped. Coyles father, Sean Coyle, called round to the flat in Preston at sometime between  and .am that morning to check on his daughter and grand-daughter and she told him to be quiet as Ellie-May was sleeping. When he went into her bedroom Hitchcott was crouched over her bed in a gap between the end of the bed and the wall.  He believed he was trying to wake Ellie-May, who was lying on her back. He askedshe was okay and he replied: “Yeah I think so.” Mr Coyle realised something was not right and when he askedshe was breathing. “When Mr Coyle looked at Ellie-May her eyes rolled back into her head and she looked ‘clammy’, the prosecution said during the trial.  Mr Coyle now knew that something terrible had happened to Ellie. An ambulance was called and after ing to the bedroom, Mr Coyle told Hitchcott to get Ellie-May, who still had the duvet over her, out of bed. Hitchcott pulled the covers about half way down the bed and put his hands under her torso and pulled and lted her up. The prosecution queried whether he was struggling to do so as her feet and legs were tied by the pink blanket and other material and he had not had time to unbind her. Mr Coyle and paramedics tried to resuscitate Ellie-May.  She was taken to the Royal Preston Hospital and was declared dead at .am. Police attending the scene found a pink and a blue blanket had been used as ligatures going under the mattress. The blue one - which would have corresponded with Ellie-May’s chest area - was undone but the pink one - which would have corresponded with her legs - was knotted and tied so tightly the sides of the mattress were raised off the bed frame by cm. Coyle later told police Hitchcott had been binding her daughter across the chest with the blue blanket since mid-January saying it would help her settle into a sleep routine and stop her banging her head on the wall.  In a statement which was read to the court, Ellie-Mays father John Minshull said: Every day me and my mum think about Ellie and really miss her, we just wish we could give her a big hug and it breaks our hearts deeply. He added: Now I cant be a dad to her no more, it destroys me inside. The couple, who both denied they had tied the youngster to the bed, were also convicted of one count of child cruelty by caging the child in her bed, and another count of child cruelty by restraining her in the bed. Their lodger, Connor Kirby, , of Octavia Court, Huyton, Liverpool, was cleared of all of the charges.

title: dad spent 10 000 accidentally
story: NewsDad who spent £, accidentally transferred into his bank account thought it was ChristmasBailey Waltons account received an unexpected bonus when his girlfriends boss accidentally added an extra  on to her wages, a court heardShareCommentsByHayley Sewell:,  NOV Updated:,  NOV NewsBailey Walton spent £, wrongly sent by his girlfriend Lauren Woods boss in a bungled bank transfer "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA father of two gave away pound, after he was mistakenly sent the money by his girlfriends boss in a bungled bank transaction. Security guard Bailey Walton, , had been struggling to pay back money he blew on betting machines until he discovered the windfall. The father of two thought it was Christmas and over the next month used the forbidden cash to pay off his debts before Lauren Woods boss Joanne Harvey realised the error. It is thought Miss Harvey, who runs a care services firm accidentally put an extra nought on the amount when paying wage money to Miss Wood by BACS. Miss Wood, , knew nothing of the windfall. At Minshull Street Crown Court, Manchester, Walton, of Little Hulton near Salford admitted theft and was ordered to pay back all the cash.  He was also sentenced to  months jail suspended for two years and and complete  unpaid work hours. Miss Wood was initially charged with theft alongside Walton but the case against her was dropped. The court heard the botched transaction occurred on July  whilst Miss Wood was employed by Miss Harvey. Walton had control of the account as Miss Wood was unable to open one and when he saw the money had been deposited he made no contact with Miss Harvey and instead secretly spent the lot. The error was discovered the following month.  Judge Bernard Lever said: The employer made a mistake and he took advantage of this. He got a bank payment and thinks it’s Christmas. He didn’t intend to steal from her - it was her error that caused the problem. The judge told Walton: Your partner was working for a small firm and therefore vulnerable to financial loss. Miss Harvey said her and the company have been caused great problems and inconvenience due to your dishonesty. Your partner didn’t have the stable conduct to have her own account so it was paid into yours. She accidentally made a bank error and gave you  times as much as you should have got, being pound,. Miss Harvey has said the actions caused by the loss to the company has caused upset as a result of your dishonesty. You were not in a position of trust but in responsibility. You have a gambling problem and money issues and you took advantage of the mistake that was made. You could have ed the money, but you dissipated it. Now you will have to pay the money back.  The court heard Walton and Miss Wood have two children, one aged six and the other a baby in need of an operation. Miss Wood currently suffers with post natal depression. Defence lawyer Adam Brown said in mitigation: They have another baby on the way and an eight week old baby currently. They are now living together whilst he works in security at night. Their son has health issues in his stomach and is due to go through chemo surgery and they are combating this together. She is battling with depression. The money has now been dissipated as he had signicant gambling debts. He had control over the account so his partner was not involved. He gave it to people who he owed money to and he regrets doing it.  He had demonstrated that he can remain out of trouble. He attended the police station to admit to what he did. A reference from his employer said he has worked on door security for  years and he is a credit to security. I also have a reference from a man who he helped outside of a bar he helped him. He did take advantage of the situation but it was due to his own financial situation. Prosecuting Andrew Evans said earlier: He received a bank error of pound, but there was no further contact with the employer. His partner was completely unaware of the money going into that account. Charges have since been discontinued against his partner.

Researchers who carried out a detailed study found one in six do two hours of work over Saturday and Sunday - and one in  do three hours. story: NewsInside Prince Charles lavish th birthday party including who Prince Edward sawed in halfAround  guests attended the Prince of Wales Buckingham Palace soiree on WednesdayShareCommentsByZoe ShentonUS Showbiz Editor :,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror am celebrity-news video prince-charles-receives-balloon-th-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get Royal Family updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailPrince Charles celebrated his th birthday this week with a lavish party hosted by The Queen at Buckingham Palace. Edward, armed with a hand saw, got on stage to perform the old classic illusion for guests. The newspaper also reports that no one danced more enthusiastically in the Palace ballroom than Charles and we Camilla. Musical entertainment on the night was provided by Jools Holland, singer and actor Gary Wilmot, tenor and actor Alfie Boe, and US soprano Renee Fleming.  Other entertainment came in the form of a Welsh choir, Chinese acrobats and Canadian comedian Michel Lauziere, who is known for his novelty standup performances. After guests enjoyed drinks in the Picture Gallery, they then made their way to the ballroom where they feasted on salmon tartlet, poussin with autumn vegetables and an ice cream bombe dessert. Tables were reportedly decorated with blue table clothes, candlesticks and flowers from Highgrove Royal Gardens, which is the Prince of Wales and the Duchess of Cornwalls private residence. The Queen paid tribute to her son with a heart-warming toast saying: “It is a privilege for any mother to be able to propose a toast to her son on his th birthday. It means that you have lived long enough to see your child grow up. It is rather like —to use an analogy I am certain will find favour — planting a tree and being able to watch it grow. My mother saw me turn , of course. And she was heard to observe that  is exactly the age when the number of candles on your cake finally exceeds the amount of breath you have to blow them out.  Over his  years, Philip and I have seen Charles become a champion of conservation and the arts, a great charitable leader — a dedicated and respected heir to the throne to stand comparison with any in history — and a wonderful father. Most of all, sustained by his we Camilla, he is his own man, passionate and creative. So this toast is to wish a happy birthday to my son, in every respect a duchy original. To you Charles. To the Prince of Wales.” Other notable guests included Prince Albert of Monaco, Dame Maggie Smith, Dame Judi Dench and Queen Rania of Jordan.

title: man suing british airways says
story: NewsMan suing British Airways says Jonah Lomu-sized passenger gave him back spasmsStephen Prosser, , from Tonypandy, South Wales, claims he suffered "soft tissue damage" on the -hour flight from Bangkok to HeathrowShareByElaine McCahill:,  NOV NewsStephen Prosser, , is suing British Airwas for £k claiming he was injured after being sat next to a large passenger "Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailA businessman who is suing British Airways told a court he was injured after being forced to squeeze into a seat next to an obese man who was the size of Jonah Lomu. Stephen Prosser, , claims he suffered soft tissue damage after the man wedged himself into the seat next to him. The company director claims he suffered personal injury and loss of earnings after being made to sit next to the large passenger during a -hour flight from Bangkok to Heathrow. On Friday, Pontypridd County Court heard the self-employed civil engineer claim cabin crew ignored his complaints that he would be injuredforced to sit next to the extremely large passenger, who he described as being ft in and weighing approximately  stones. Mr Prosser, who is ft in, said: He was that large that he had to force his buttocks between the arm rests of the seats.  I sat with his knees wedged against the seat in front and the rest of his body was over spilling into my seat by some inches. I was immediately aware that this was going to be problematic for me and I could feel the weight of his pure bulk putting lateral pressure on my upper body. This forced me into a position of unnatural posture. Due to the size of him when he placed his arm down at times it would rest on my armrest, and he would accidentally turn the volume of my audio up to an extremely loud volume each time. He said he chose not to take issue with the passenger because he seemed self conscious, but did complain to cabin crew, who allegedly told him there were no other seats available on the fully booked Boeing  and did not allow him to swap with someone .  Mr Prosser, from Penygraig in Tonypandy, South Wales, said the incident in January  left him with a continual back spasm and an injury causing his sacroiliac joint at the bottom of his spine to dys. He said being forced into an unnatural position during the long haul flight also aggravated his -year-old spine injury caused by driving long distances for work. He said he had been unable to work overtime as a result of his back pain, and left him lacking energy which had affected his relationship with his partner and forced him to give up mountain biking. Jack Harding, representing Mr Prosser, said the unusual case fell under the Montreal Convention , a treaty adopted by members states of the International Civil Aviation Organization concerning compensation for the victims of air disasters. Mr Harding said a figure of pound, had been submitted for the loss of earnings claim.  Timothy Salisbury, representing British Airways, said Mr Prosser was exaggerating by comparing the other passenger to the late New Zealand rugby legend Jonah Lomu, who was ft ins and weighed  stones. Mr Salisbury said: You say the man reminded you of the late rugby player Jonah Lomu. Would you say thats a colourful explanation  An exaggeration  Mr Prosser replied: Not at all. Mr Salisbury said cabin crew on the flight described the passenger as tall but not overweight so he had encroached on the other seat. Chris McLindon, the customer service manager on board the flight, said in a witness statement Mr Prosser did not seem to be in any discomfort and at times he was asleep.  Mr McLindon saida customer of the size Mr Prosser has claimed was on board they would have required an extension to their seat belt to fit around their body, and would also have had trouble lowering their armrest. Asked by District Judge Andrew Barcello what would happena passenger too large for the seats boarded the aircraft, Mr McLindon said: They would have to buy two seats. District Judge Andrew Barcello said he would reserve judgment and would schedule a hearing to announce the outcome of the case.

story: NewsWhat its like to live in the house from an infamous murder mysteryThe locked room murder of Julia Wallace in Liverpool has baffled detectives and amateur sleuths for decadesShareCommentsByEmilia BonaFred Nathan:,  NOV Newsthis.style.displaynone" Video LoadingVideo UnavailableClick to playTap to playThe video will start in CancelPlay now,adData:,videoData:,mainEntityOfPage:https:www.mirror news uk-news video unsolved-locked-room-murder-,customFields:,suggestedData:,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,,],gtmContainerId:GTM-MTHP,gtmFbiaContainerId:GTM-PNLXFZS,trackingData:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true,info:,article:,info:],hasLeadVideo:true,interaction:,features:,video.header.bidding.enabled:,bundledCss:,recommendations:https:mab.data.tm-awx rhs,modularCss:true,newslettersURL:https:communicatoremail F QVgiPbuQPTrjCOF~PhHv_ ,nativeAppBanner:true""Get daily news updates directly to your inboxSubscribeSee our privacy noticeMore newslettersThank you for subscribingWe have more newslettersShow meSee our privacy noticeCould not subscribe, try again laterInvalid EmailOn a dark, winter night in , William Herbert Wallace ed to his Liverpool home to find his we brutally bludgeoned to death inside a locked house. There was no sign of a murder weapon and no clues left behind as to who killed her. The locked room murder became infamous, with the gruesome and unusual details of the case inspiring crime novels and TV dramas. But what is it like to actually live in the house behind one of Liverpools greatest mysteries  More than  years later, the impossible murder that baffled detectives remains unsolved - but the cold case continues to attract amateur sleuths set on cracking it. On the night of January , Julias husband William came home to find the house completely locked and blanketed in total darkness.  After calling on his neighbours John and Florence Johnston for help, Wallace walked into the house, lit a lamp and came back out saying: Oh come and see, shes been killed. When the couple entered the Wallace home, they found -year-old Julie sprawled out in the sitting room in front of the gas fire, having been beaten to death. The room was a scene of utter horror, with Julias leless body lying in a pool of her own blood, and splatters from the attack sprayed across the walls.  Staring at his wes battered and beaten body, Wallace turned to his neighbours and said: Theyve finished her, look at her brains. The Liverpool Echo spoke to the family who moved into the Wolverton Street property at the centre of the chilling tale and asked what its like living at an address famous for a grizzly murder. John Taylor was actually born and raised on Wolverton Street, in the shadow of Liverpool FCs Anfield stadium, moving into the Wallaces old house across the road in .  John knew all about the history of Number  when he moved into the property - its impossible to live on Wolverton Street and not know about it. It all unfolded in the front room of the couples Wolverton Street home, where John now lives with his children Oliver, seven, and Rubin, three. However, John said the houses history didnt bother him in the slightest when he chose to move in. He said: I knew all about the murder - Ive lived in the street all my le. It didnt bother me at all. I grew up with it - they did films in the street. I knew all about it - Im not really one for ghosts and things like that. Im not scared of anything like that.  While John might not be bothered by the propertys macabre history, his carefree attitude isnt shared by everyone who visits the house. Although John doesnt believe in ghosts, hauntings or supernatural goings-on, friends and family have certainly felt a spooky presence in the property. The -year-old dad-of-two added: A few people have felt a few things in the house - things brushing past you. My mate had something brush past him - Ive had it too.  Something has been on my mates lap - a pen - and it literally flew across the room, like someone threw it over the room. Its not really scared me at all. But Johns partner Jane Owings is slightly more unsettled by the houses gruesome history. She said: John reckons he has felt things. His friend over the road said someone has blown on him. I always say dont tell me - Ill be too scared!  EvenI did feel something I would ignore it! John got a film on the murder and wanted to watch it and I was like no way! The impossible murder at Wolverton Street took place more than  years ago, and unsurprisingly the property has been considerably modernised over the years. However, some original features remain in the property - offering a hidden reminder of the houses history. Knowing what unfolded in the front room of the house on that night in , Jane thought it was best to move things around to try and put it out of her mind.  She added: Some things are still the original features in there, like the ceiling. I changed where the living room was and we dont really use it. We shut the door and use it for Christmas dinner. The the dog starts barking and Im thinking I cant hear anything! Despite the decades that have passed since the murder took place, the case continues to fascinate people and the details live on in the memories of locals.  Telling people you live in a house associated with such an infamous case attracts its fair share of attention, with John saying: People are sort of fascinated and askyouve seen anything in the house. Jane said: Its quite interesting when you tell people or taxi drivers will tell you thats a famous house they dont believe you live there! Since Wallaces death, the case of Julias murder has never been solved.  The mystery has attracted countless theorists and armchair detectives to put forward their own suggestions for who was behind the crime. Julias murder even inspired a number of murder mysteries - including P.D. James  crime novel The Skull Beneath the Skin.

The Child and Youth Advocacy Centre are investigating the clips alongside Toronto Police. Police have warned anyone in possession of the video could face potential child porn charges. “Investigators from the Child Exploitation Section have been consulted and have determined the video meets the definition of child pornography,” police said in a statement. “Anyone who has this video is in possession of child pornography. The video must be deleted immediately and cannot be shared with anyone.” The school said they were investigating the incident in the locker room internally before reporting it to police on November . Four students were expelled in connection the the washroom incident, while the other four were expelled in connection to the alleged sexual assault, the school said. While St Michaels have not released details of those involved, school officials and football coaches met with members of the football team and their parents on Thursday. The school has confirmed it has cancelled its junior football season.  The school said in a statement: This week, to our shock and dismay, we learned of two incidents that were in clear violation of our Student Code of Conduct. The school has zero tolerance for such behaviour. The school administration promptly conducted an internal investigation, including meeting inidually with the students involved and their parents. As a result, swt and decisive disciplinary action has taken place, including expulsions. We are deeply sorry that these incidents occurred. From this unfortunate situation, we redouble our efforts to educate and promote respect for others in the school and in the community.”
